label: compound
description: A word or name that combines two or more words without altering them, such as [_dishcloth_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dishcloth#English) (from [_dish_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dish#English) and [_cloth_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cloth#English)) or [_high school_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/high_school#English) (from [_high_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/high#English) and [_school_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/school#English)); the latter type is called an [open compound](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/open_compound). Compound terms are indicated in etymologies using {{[compound](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Template:compound#top)}}. (See also [_Wiktionary:Etymology § Compound_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Etymology#Compound).)

label: conjugation
description: The [inflection](#inflection) of [verbs](#verb). See also [_declension_](#declension).

label: transliteration
description: The conversion of text in one [script](#script) into an equivalent in another [script](#script), or an instance of text so converted (for example, _Ševčenko_ and _Shevchenko_ are transliterations of Ukrainian _Шевченко_ from Cyrillic script to Latin script, according to two different systems). / Transliteration is conducted on a letter-by-letter basis (contrasted with [transcription](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/transcription) which is converted on the basis of sounds). This may be extended to the conversion of [diacritical](#diacritic) marks into alternate forms without diacritical marks in the same script (e.g. _Mörder_ → _Moerder_).

label: تَصْحِيف
description: When a copyist has set wrong points ([ʾiʿjām](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/i%27jam)) upon the skeleton ([rasm](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rasm)) of the (Arabic) script.

label: a.
description: [Ante](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ante) (Latin for "before"). Hence, a quotation from "_a._ 1924" is a quotation from no later than the year 1923.

label: ablative case
description: A [case](#case) that indicates separation, or moving away from something. It is used alone or with certain [prepositions](#preposition). For example, if English had a fully [productive](#productive) case system that included the ablative case, then in the phrase _came from the city_, either "the city" or "from the city" would likely be in the ablative. In some languages, such as Latin, this case has acquired many other uses and does not strictly indicate separation anymore.

label: abstract noun
description: A [noun](#noun) that denotes an idea, emotion, feeling, quality or other abstract or intangible concept, as opposed to a concrete item, or a physical object. [Antonym](#antonym) of [concrete noun](#concrete_noun).

label: abstract verb
description: _See [_multidirectional verb_](#multidirectional_verb)._

label: accusative case
description: A [case](#case) that is usually used as the [direct object](#direct_object) of a [verb](#verb). For example, if English had a fully [productive](#productive) case system, then _ball_ in "The man threw the ball" would most likely be in the accusative.

label: active voice
description: The [voice](#voice) verb form in which the grammatical [subject](#subject) is the person or thing doing the action (compare [passive voice](#passive_voice)), e.g. _The boy kicked the ball._ (See also [_voice_](#voice))

label: AD
description: [Anno Domini](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/anno_Domini) (Latin for "in the year of the Lord"). Year-numbering system equivalent to [CE](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/CE).

label: adj
description: _See [_adjective_](#adjective)._

label: adverb
description: A word like [_very_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/very#English), [_wickedly_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wickedly#English) or [_often_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/often#English) that usually serves to modify an [adjective](#adjective), [verb](#verb), or other adverb.

label: adverbial
description: Relating to an [adverb](#adverb). For example, an _adverbial participle_ is a [participle](#participle) that functions like an adverb in a sentence.

label: adverbial clause
description: A type of [dependent clause](#dependent_clause) that modifies a verb in an [adverbial](#adverbial) fashion. Examples are _When my friend arrives, I will take him out to dinner_ and _If it rains, I will go home_ (the latter example being specifically a _conditional clause_).

label: AHD
description: The [American Heritage Dictionary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Heritage_Dictionary). / For historical reasons, this abbreviation is sometimes used here to identify a respelled pronunciation that is given in [enPR](#enPR) form.

label: animate
description: Having a [referent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/referent) that includes a human or animal. Many languages (such as the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages)) classify nouns based on animacy, using different [inflections](#inflection) or words with animate and inanimate nouns.

label: antepenultima
description: The third-to-last [syllable](#syllable) of a word, before the [penultima](#penultima).

label: antonym
description: A word with a meaning that is the opposite of a meaning of another word. For example, [_good_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/good#English) is an antonym of [_bad_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bad#English). / Contrast [synonym](#synonym).

label: aorist
description: A grammatical category of [verbs](#verb) that is often a [perfective](#perfective) past.

label: aphesis
description: The removal or omission of an initial unstressed vowel from a word, a type of [apheresis](#apheresis).

label: applicative
description: A grammatical voice or verb form where an oblique argument of the verb is promoted to a core argument.

label: approximant
description: A [consonant](#consonant) sound produced by restricting the air flow through the mouth only slightly, resulting in a smooth sound. In English, the approximants are /l/, /ɹ/, /w/, /j/ (as in the initial sounds of _loo_, _rue_, _woo_ and _you_). Approximants are distinguished from [fricatives](#fricative), in which the air is constricted enough to cause a rough, hissing or buzzing sound, and [plosives](#plosive), in which the air is blocked completely for a short period of time.

label: archaic
description: No longer in general use, but still found in some contemporary texts that aim for an antique style, like historical novels. For example, [_thee_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thee#English) and [_thou_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thou#English) are archaic pronouns, having been almost completely superseded by [_you_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/you#English). _Archaic_ is a stronger term than [_dated_](#dated), but not as strong as [_obsolete_](#obsolete). (See [Wiktionary:Obsolete and archaic terms](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Obsolete_and_archaic_terms).) Whereas an archaic term names a still-extant thing or non-outdated concept, a [historical](#historical) term names a former thing or outdated concept.

label: areal
description: Distributed across multiple languages inhabiting a particular area, due to [language contact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/language_contact) among them rather than due to [inheritance](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/inheritance) from a common ancestor. The term can be applied either to words (see [_loanword_](#loanword)) or features of languages such as in [grammar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/grammar), [morphology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/morphology), and [phonology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/phonology). See also [_Wanderwort_](#wanderwort) and [_stratum_](#stratum).

label: article
description: A type of [determiner](#determiner) that is used as a grammatical indicator in some languages, and is usually central to the grammar and syntax of that language. In English, the articles are the [definite](#definite) article [_the_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/the#English), and the [indefinite](#indefinite) articles [_a_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/a#English) and [_an_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/an#English). Some languages may have more articles, such as the French [partitive](#partitive) articles [_du_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/du#French), [_de la_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/de_la#French) and [_des_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/des#French), while many languages lack articles altogether.

label: aspect
description: A property of a verb form indicating the nature of an action as [perfective](#perfective) (complete) or [imperfective](#imperfective) (incomplete or continuing).

label: aspiratedh
description: In French, an initial ⟨h⟩ that is treated as a [consonant](#consonant); that is to say, [liaison](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/liaison) and [elision](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/elision) are not permitted at the beginning of a word with an aspirated ⟨h⟩.

label: assimilation
description: Assimilation is a common phonological process by which one sound becomes more like a nearby sound. This can occur either within a word or between words. See also [_dissimilation_](#dissimilation).

label: atelic
description: The [aspect](#aspect) of a verb that denotes an action without a definite endpoint or a goal that is tended towards, or rather an action with [cumulative reference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cumulativity_(linguistics)) (such that the expression for that action may describe two or more actions of that kind that, when combined, still constitute a form of that action); contrast [**telic**](#telic). A kind of telicity distinction can be seen in English when specifying a duration in a (simple past) verb phrase: atelic verb phrases take [_for_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/for#English) (_I built a house for an hour._ _She loved me for years._) (See also [](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telicity) [**Telicity**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telicity) on Wikipedia.)

label: attributive
description: See also: [_Appendix:English nouns § Attributive_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:English_nouns#Attributive) An adjective that stands in a syntactic position where it directly modifies a noun, as opposed to a [predicative](#predicative) adjective, which stands in a [predicate](#predicate) position but which modifies the [subject](#subject) of the [clause](#clause). For example, in _the big green house_, _big_ and _green_ are attributive adjectives, whereas in _The house is big and green_, _big_ and _green_ are predicative adjectives. Some adjectives are only-attributive like [_close_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/close#Adjective) (in _a close friend_) or [_plain_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plain#English) (in _plain nonsense_). A noun or adjective (or phrase) that names a real object with the _attributes_ of another real object. For example, a [noun adjunct](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noun_adjunct). This is in contrast to a [substantive](#substantive) noun or adjective, which names a real object that is the actual _substance_ named by the noun or adjective.

label: augment
description: In some [Indo-European](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Indo-European) languages, a prefixed [vowel](#vowel) (e.g., Sanskrit [_अ-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E0%A4%85-#Sanskrit:_augment) (a-) and Ancient Greek [_ἐ-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%90-#Ancient_Greek) (e-)) indicating a past tense in a verb. In [Celtic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Celtic) languages, especially Old Irish, a preverb, usually [_ro-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ro-#Old_Irish), used to give a verb a resultative or potential meaning. In certain Bantu languages, a [morpheme](#morpheme) prefixed to a [noun class](#noun_class) prefix.

label: augmentative
description: A word form expressing large size, importance, intensity, or seniority.

label: augmentless
description: (of nouns) Lacking an [augment](#augment).

label: auxiliary verb or auxiliary
description: A verb that accompanies another verb in a clause. It is used to indicate distinctions in [tense](#tense), [mood](#mood), [voice](#voice), [aspect](#aspect) or other grammatical nuances. English examples are [_can_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/can#English), [_will_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/will#English), [_have_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/have#English), [_be_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/be#English).

label: avoidance term
description: A word standardly used to replace a [taboo](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/taboo) word.

label: back-formation
description: A term formed by reinterpretation, or [reanalysis](#reanalysis) of an older term, often by removing an apparent or real prefix or suffix from it; for example, the noun [_pea_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pea#English) arose because the final /z/ sound in [_pease_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pease#English) sounded like a plural suffix. Similarly, the verb [_edit_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/edit#English) is a back-formation from the earlier noun [_editor_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/editor#English). Not to be confused with [clipping](#clipping), which just shortens a word without changing meaning or part of speech.

label: back vowel
description: Vowel sound produced in the back of the mouth. Examples in English include /uː/ in [rule](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rule#English) or /əʊ/ in [pole](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pole#English). / Contrast [front vowel](#front_vowel).

label: backronym
description: A word that is either not an [acronym](#acronym) but is taken to be one and for which a full form is invented by [back-formation](#back-formation), or is an acronym and for which an alternative full form is invented by back-formation.

label: backslang
description: A form of [slang](#slang) in which the spelling of words is reversed.

label: bahuvrihi
description: Another term for an [_exocentric_](#exocentric) compound. / Contrast [_tatpurusa_](#tatpurusa), [_karmadharaya_](#karmadharaya) and [_dvandva_](#dvandva).

label: barytone
description: With the stress elsewhere than upon the final syllable. Compare with [oxytone](#oxytone), [paroxytone](#paroxytone), and [proparoxytone](#proparoxytone).

label: base state
description: In Luganda, the form of a [noun](#noun) in which there is not an [initial vowel](#initial_vowel). / Contrast [_topic state_](#topic_state).

label: BC
description: Before Christ. Year-numbering system equivalent to [BCE](#BCE).

label: BCE
description: Before the Common, Current or Christian Era. Year-numbering system equivalent to [BC](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/BC). [AD](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/AD) is expressed as [CE](#CE). To automatically switch most dates to use the "BC"/"AD" style, check the Gadgets section in [Special:Preferences](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Preferences) (or [WT:PREFS](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:PREFS) if you do not have an account).

label: blend
description: A word or name that combines two words, typically starting with the start of one word and ending with the end of another, such as [_smog_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/smog#English) (from [_smoke_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/smoke#English) and [_fog_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fog#English)). Many blends are [portmanteaus](#portmanteau). / See also [_merger_](#merger).

label: borrowing
description: See [_loanword_](#loanword).

label: bound form
description: A unit of language that can only be used as part of a word, not as a word on its own (such as the English suffix -ly). These types of [morphemes](#morpheme) are ‘bound’ in that they are restricted on where and how they are allowed to occur, needing to be attached to a freestanding morpheme in order to exist. Many suffixes are often bound.

label: bowdlerization
description: The removal, from a text, of words or phrases that are considered offensive or vulgar.

label: broadly
description: Indicates a less precise (wider) use of words; short for _broadly speaking_. For most practical purposes, synonymous with [_loosely_](#loosely). / Contrast [_strict_](#strict) (_narrow_) senses.

label: broken plural
description: An [irregular](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/irregular) [plural](#plural) formed by changing the pattern of [vowels](#vowel) inside the [singular](#singular) form, found in the [Semitic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semitic_languages) and other [Afroasiatic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages) such as the [Berber languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berber_languages). Examples in Arabic are [_كُتُب_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%83%D8%AA%D8%A8#Arabic) (kutub, “books”) and [_مَكَاتِب_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D9%83%D8%A7%D8%AA%D8%A8#Arabic) (makātib, “desks”), respectively the plural forms of [_كِتَاب_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%83%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8#Arabic) (kitāb, “book”) and [_مَكْتَب_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D9%83%D8%AA%D8%A8#Arabic) (maktab, “desk”). Compare plurals in English formed by internal processes such as [umlaut](#umlaut), as with [_teeth_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/teeth#English), plural of [_tooth_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tooth#English). Broken plurals contrast with [_sound plurals_](#sound_plural), which are formed by adding an ending to the singular (similarly to how plurals are typically formed in English and most other languages).

label: c.
description: [Circa](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/circa) (Latin for "about"). Hence, a quotation from "c. 1924" or "ca. 1924" is a quotation from approximately 1924.

label: calque
description: A borrowing by word-for-word or [morpheme](#morpheme)-for-morpheme translation: a [loan translation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/loan_translation). For example, the English expression [_it goes without saying_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/it_goes_without_saying#English) is a calque (a literal, word-for-word translation) of French [_ça va sans dire_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%C3%A7a_va_sans_dire#French), and [_flea market_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/flea_market#English) is a calque of French [_marché aux puces_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/march%C3%A9_aux_puces#French) (literally “[market](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/market) with [fleas](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/flea)”). Contrariwise, the term [_skyscraper_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/skyscraper#English) was calqued into French as [_gratte-ciel_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/gratte-ciel#French) (literally “scrapes-sky”). / Calques are distinguished from [semantic loans](#semantic_loan) in that calques are not considered idiomatic expressions at the time that they are coined, whereas semantic loans would have had a pre-existing idiomatic meaning.

label: case
description: One of the forms of a noun, used to indicate its function in the phrase or sentence. Examples include: [nominative](#nominative_case), [accusative](#accusative_case), [genitive](#genitive_case), [dative](#dative_case).

label: cat.
description: Abbreviation for [_category_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/category#English).

label: category
description: A collection of entries, used to categorize or group entries of words that are similar in syntax (for example, English plural nouns) or in sense (for example, English words pertaining to sports); _see_ [Wiktionary:Categorization](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Categorization).

label: catenative verb
description: A [verb](#verb) able to be immediately followed by the full or bare [infinitive](#infinitive), or [gerund](#gerund) (i.e. non-finite verbs). / → [Appendix:English catenative verbs](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:English_catenative_verbs)

label: causative verb
description: A transitive verb that is derived from another verb, and expresses the act of making someone/something do the action of the base verb. Examples in English are: [_lay_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lay#English) (cause to [_lie_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lie#English)), [_set_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/set#English) (cause to [_sit_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sit#English)) and [_raise_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/raise#English) (cause to [_rise_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rise#English)). Compare [**factitive verbs**](#factitive) (e.g. [_shorten_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shorten#English), [_enslave_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/enslave#English)), which are similar but are derived from adjectives or nouns.

label: CE
description: Common, Current or Christian Era. Year-numbering system equivalent to [AD](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/AD). To automatically switch most dates to use the "BC"/"AD" style, check the Gadgets section in [Special:Preferences](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Preferences) (or [WT:PREFS](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:PREFS) if you do not have an account).

label: censored
description: Of a spelling, a word that is censored possibly as a euphemism, or sometimes to bypass the chat filter, as in Spanish [_mrd_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mrd#Spanish) from [_mierda_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mierda#Spanish) (“shit”).

label: cf.
description: Confer; "see"; "compare" – often used to indicate a word with similar, or opposite meaning.

label: childish
description: Language used colloquially by babies or children. These terms should be avoided in formal language.

label: circumfix
description: An [affix](#affix) containing both a [prefixing](#prefix) and a [suffixing](#suffix) element existing as a single [morphological](#morphological) unit. For example, the word [_embolden_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/embolden#English) consists of [_bold_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bold#English) (adjective) circumfixed with [_em- -en_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/em-_-en#English), a variant of [_en- -en_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/en-_-en#English).

label: circumlocutory
description: Refers to a roundabout or indirect way of speaking; the use of more words than necessary to express an idea.

label: CJK
description: Chinese, Japanese, Korean, (and Vietnamese); [CJK characters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CJK_characters).

label: classifier
description: _See [_counter_](#counter)._

label: clause
description: A word or group of words that functions as a single unit in the [syntax](#syntax) of a [sentence](#sentence), where the [head](#head) (or central) word is a [verb](#verb); normally distinguished from a [phrase](#phrase), which is a similar unit where the head word is some other [part of speech](#part_of_speech), such as a [noun](#noun), [adjective](#adjective) or [preposition](#preposition). For example, the [sentence](#sentence) _The man entered the house, which was large and blue_ contains two clauses, the [independent clause](#independent_clause) _The man entered the house_ and the [dependent clause](#dependent_clause) _which was large and blue_ (here the dependent clause is specifically a [relative clause](#relative_clause), although not all dependent clauses are relative clauses).

label: clipping
description: A shortening of a word, without changing meaning or part of speech. Not to be confused with [back-formation](#back-formation), which changes meaning, or [ellipsis](#ellipsis), which shortens by omission of whole words. Also differs from [abbreviation](#abbreviation), which shortens the written—rather than spoken—form of a word or phrase. / See also [_apheresis_](#apheresis), [_apocope_](#apocope).

label: clitic
description: A word that attaches to a phrase and cannot be used on its own, such as English [_'s_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%27s#English). Many languages have clitic [pronouns](#pronouns) ([weak pronouns](#weak_pronoun)), which may be contrasted with [emphatic](#emphatic) or [strong](#strong) pronouns; for example, English [_'ll_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%27ll#English) is a clitic version of [_will_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/will#English) and generally attaches to the preceding word (_he'll_, _a little dab'll do ya_).

label: cognate
description: [Descended](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/descend) from the same source [lexeme](#lexeme) of an [ancestor](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ancestor) language.

label: coinage
description: A new term intentionally created with a definite meaning.

label: collective
description: Expressing a collection or aggregate of individuals by a [singular](#singular) form. / → [Category:Collective nouns by language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Collective_nouns_by_language)

label: collocation
description: A sequence of words or terms that are used together more often than by chance, i.e. that appears together relatively more often. A collocation under a particular definition of a polysemic term should reflect a sequence that distinguishes usage with the particular definition from most other definitions of the term.

label: colloquial
description: Denotes words belonging to a spoken or vernacular variety of a language. These words are only properly used in a casual or familiar context. / This label is only used with some languages; with others it is treated as a synonym of [_informal_](#informal). If used, _colloquial_ is stronger than _informal_ (a general rule of thumb is that informal words may be used in the running text of a newspaper article, while a colloquial term would likely not appear without quotation marks). / **Note:** It is a common misconception that _colloquial_ somehow denotes "local" or a word being "[regional](#regional)". This is incorrect; the word root for _colloquial_ is related to [_locution_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/locution#English), not [_location_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/location#English).

label: combining form
description: A particular form of a term which is used as an [affix](#affix). For example, [_Afro-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Afro-#English) (as in words like [_Afrocentric_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Afrocentric#English), [_Afro-American_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Afro-American#English)) is the _combining form_ of [_African_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/African#English).

label: common gender
description: Of common [gender](#gender). Some languages have a distinct common gender that combines [masculine](#masculine) and [feminine](#feminine) but is distinguished from [neuter](#neuter). In other languages, a "noun of common gender" is a pair of nouns, one masculine and one feminine, that are identical in form, and that have the same sense except that one refers to men and the other to women. Distinguish [epicene](#epicene).

label: comparable
description: Of an adjective or adverb: able to be compared, having [comparative](#comparative) and [superlative](#superlative) forms that end in _-er_ and _-est_ (adjectives only), or in conjunction with the words _more_ or _most_, or sometimes _further_ or _furthest_. Examples: _big_, _bigger_, and _biggest_; _talented_, _more talented_, and _most talented_; _upstairs_, _further upstairs_, and _furthest upstairs_. Some adjectives are truly [**incomparable**](#incomparable), such as _daily_, _additional_, and _else_. Many other adjectives, such as _unique_, _existential_, and _bearable_ are generally considered incomparable, but controversially so, where examples can be readily cited of something being "_more bearable_" or "_most perfect_".

label: comparative
description: An [inflection](#inflection), or different form, of a [**comparable**](#comparable) adjective showing a relative quality, usually denoting "to a greater extent" but not "to the ultimate extent". (See also [_superlative_](#superlative) and [_degrees of comparison_](#degrees_of_comparison).) In English, the _comparative_ form is usually formed by appending _-er_, or using the word _more_. For example, the comparative of _hard_ is "_harder_"; of _difficult_, "_more difficult_".

label: concrete noun
description: A [noun](#noun) that denotes something tangible or material, such as a person or place. [Antonym](#antonym) of [abstract noun](#abstract_noun).

label: concrete verb
description: _See [_unidirectional verb_](#unidirectional_verb)._

label: conditional mood
description: The [mood](#mood) of a [verb](#verb) used to signify that something is [contingent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/contingent) upon the outcome of something else. The conditional mood in English is normally introduced by the word _would_, as in _If I were rich, I would be happy_.

label: conflation
description: _See [_contamination_](#contamination)._

label: connegative
description: A [verb](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verb) form used with the [negative verb](#negative_verb).

label: connotation
description: The [subjective](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/subjective) and non[analytical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/analytical) meaning (definition) of a word, such as its emotional overtones, as contrasted with its [objective](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/objective) and [analytical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/analytical) meaning (definition), which constitutes its [denotation](#denotation) (an example is given there).

label: consonant
description: Any sound that is not the dominant sound of a [syllable](#syllable), the dominant sound generally being a [vowel](#vowel).

label: consonantism
description: The sequence of [consonants](#consonant), or the quality peculiar to the consonants of a given word or group of words.

label: consonant gradation
description: A form of consonant [mutation](#mutation) found in certain, particularly Uralic, languages, which is historically conditioned by the openness of the following syllable.

label: construct state
description: In some languages, a grammatical form that is used in construing a noun or adjective with another noun or adjective. In the [Semitic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Semitic) languages, the construct form is usually a noun modified by a following noun in a genitive construction. The construct state of such a noun _X_ can usually be translated to English as _X of_. In [Persian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Persian), the construct state is typically used for all nouns and adjectives in a [noun phrase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noun_phrase) except the very last.

label: contamination
description: The influence of one term on the development of another term whereby they come to have similar meanings or a similar sound; [conflation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/conflation). Extreme cases of conflation can result in a [merger](#merger) or [blend](#blend) of two words.

label: contraction
description: A word or phrase shortened in speech, sometimes represented in writing with a [punctuation mark](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/punctuation_mark) in place of missing letters (e.g. English _[_do_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/do#English) [_not_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/not#English)_ → [_don't_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/don%27t#English) or Romanian _[_nu_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nu#Romanian) [_e_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/e#Romanian)_ → [_nu-i_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nu-i#Romanian)).

label: contranym
description: A term with two opposite meanings.

label: conversion
description: The process whereby a new word is created without changing the form, often by allowing the word to function as a new part of speech.

label: coordinate term
description: A term that is a different type of the same [hypernym](#hypernym) (loosely "category"). _Car_ and _bicycle_ are coordinate terms to each other, both being [hyponyms](#hyponym) of a shared [hypernym](#hypernym) _vehicle_. Although the term can be applied broadly – e.g. _car_ and _asteroid_ are both _things_ –, such usage is not useful in Wiktionary.

label: coordinative compound
description: A [nominal](#nominal) [compound](#compound) in which the two parts are coordinated and the intended meaning of the compound as a whole is a combination of the two parts. Also known as a [_dvandva_](#dvandva) compound. Examples in English are not common but are found in many other languages, e.g. Greek [_μαχαιροπίρουνο_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%87%CE%B1%CE%B9%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%80%CE%AF%CF%81%CE%BF%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%BF#Greek) (machairopírouno, “cutlery”, literally “knife-fork”) and Yiddish [_טאַטע־מאַמע_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D7%98%D7%90%D6%B7%D7%98%D7%A2%D6%BE%D7%9E%D7%90%D6%B7%D7%9E%D7%A2#Yiddish) (tate-mame, “parents”, literally “papa-mama”). / Contrast [exocentric](#exocentric) and [endocentric](#endocentric) compounds.

label: copula
description: A verb that links and equates its [subject](#subject) with its object; also called a [linking verb](#linking_verb). The most common copula is the verb _to be_, but others exist, such as _to seem_, _to appear_ and _to sound_. The object of a copula often has special properties. For example, it can be an [adjective](#adjective) (_John is very tall, the water runs cold_) when most verbs require their objects to be [nouns](#noun) or [pronouns](#pronoun). In addition, in languages with [case](#case) distinctions, the object of a copula is most commonly in the [nominative](#nominative) case, while the object of other verbs is usually in a different case, such as the [accusative](#accusative) case. Many languages (e.g. Arabic, Hebrew, Russian) use a _null copula_ (i.e. no word at all) in the present tense when English would use the words _am_, _are_ or _is_.

label: corpus
description: A [collection](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/collection#Noun) of [writings](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/writing#Noun), often a large one such as a [libraryful](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/libraryful#Noun) of [documents](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/document#Noun) in a particular [language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/language#Noun), and sometimes a [subset](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/subset#Noun), such as those from a specific [era](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/era#Noun), a specific [demographic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/demographic#Noun), a specific [genre](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/genre#Noun) or [register](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/register#English:_language_register), or a particular [author](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/author#Noun); also, such a collection in the form of an electronic [database](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/database) used for [linguistic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/linguistic) analyses. [Dictionaries](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dictionary#Noun) are built using the builders' own command of a language plus reliance on many [quotations](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/quotation) ([quotes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/quote#Noun)) from [corpora](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/corpus#Noun), which in [lexicography](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lexicography) are often called [citations](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/citation#Noun). Wiktionary offers help with finding and citing citations at [Wiktionary:Quotations/Resources](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Quotations/Resources) and a deeper list at [Wiktionary:Corpora](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Corpora).

label: corruption
description: A change in the form of a word, expression or text in a non-specific, sporadic or nonstandard way, often as a result of [misunderstanding](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/misunderstanding), [mispronunciation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mispronunciation) or [mistranscription](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mistranscription). Some linguistic scientists avoid using this term for [language change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/language_change) because it connotes [prescriptive](#prescriptive) value judgments about language changes that "should have been prevented" or that "have [debased](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/debase) the language." In contrast, linguistic science's [epistemology](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/epistemology) of language does not hold that a [pidgin](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pidgin#Noun), for example, is "inferior" to the languages from which it was formed. The term _corruption_ as applied to language change was long widely used, though, even in dictionaries, and is still widely encountered. In many cases, where an older dictionary might say that word X is a corruption of word Y, some newer dictionaries might say that word X is by alteration from word Y.

label: count form
description: In some [Slavic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Slavic) [languages](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/language), such as [Bulgarian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Bulgarian) and [Russian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Russian), a [distinct](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/distinct) [plural](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plural) form taken by certain [nouns](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noun) when explicitly modified by a [quantity](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/quantity).

label: countable
description: Describes a noun which can be freely used with the [indefinite article](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/indefinite_article) (_a_ or _an_ in English) and with numbers, and which therefore has a [plural](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plural) form. [Antonym](#antonym) of [_uncountable_](#uncountable) or _mass noun_.

label: counter
description: In linguistics, counters, [measure words](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/measure_word) or [classifiers](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/classifier) are words that are used in combination with a numeral to indicate an amount of something represented by some noun. They denote a unit or measurement and are used with [mass nouns](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mass_noun), and sometimes also with [count nouns](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/count_noun). (Compare [_singulative_](#singulative).)

label: dated
description: Formerly in common use, and still in occasional use, but now unfashionable; for example, [_wireless_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wireless#English) in the sense of "broadcast radio tuner", [_groovy_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/groovy#English), and [_gay_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/gay#English) in the sense of "bright" or "happy" are all dated. _Dated_ is not as strong as [_archaic_](#archaic) or [_obsolete_](#obsolete). See [Wiktionary:Obsolete and archaic terms](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Obsolete_and_archaic_terms).

label: dative case
description: A [case](#case) that is usually used as the [indirect object](#indirect_object) of a verb. For example, if English had a fully [productive](#productive) case system, then _him_ in "She gave him the ball" would most likely be in the dative.

label: declension
description: The [inflection](#inflection) of [nouns](#noun) and words like them, or used together with them (i.e. [nominals](#nominal)). See also [_conjugation_](#conjugation).

label: defective
description: Normally would be expected to have a full set of [inflected](#inflection) forms, but some of the inflections do not exist or are never used. Examples include the English defective verbs [_can_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/can#English) and [_shall_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shall#English), which do not have [infinitive](#infinitive) forms (there is no *_to can_ or *_to shall_), or the French verb [_falloir_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/falloir#French), whose finite forms occur only in the third person singular ([_il faut_](https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=il_faut&action=edit&redlink=1); there is no *_je faus_ or *_ils fallent_).

label: defective spelling
description: In languages with [matres lectionis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mater_lectionis) ([consonant](#consonant) letters representing [vowels](#vowel)), the form including no additional ones. The opposite is called [plene spelling](#plene_spelling) when its the standardized spelling and [excessive spelling](#excessive_spelling) when it has even more of those letters than the standard spelling requires.

label: definite
description: Refers to forms of words that present something as known, identified, or immediately identifiable; in English, this is the basic meaning of the [article](#article) [_the_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/the#English); in some languages, this is a nominal or adjectival [inflection](#inflection). In the Germanic languages, adjectives inflected as definite are referred to as "weak". In Hungarian, the definite conjugation is used to indicate [definite objects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_verbs#Definite_and_indefinite_conjugations), including _him__, her_, _it__, them_, and the formal _you_.

label: degrees of comparison
description: [Inflections](#inflection) of adjectives and adverbs which allow comparisons. English has three _degrees of comparison_: [positive](#positive), [comparative](#comparative) and [superlative](#superlative). Some other languages have other degrees, e.g.: [comparative superlative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/comparative_superlative), [relative superlative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/relative_superlative), [elative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/elative).

label: demonym
description: A [noun](#noun) or [adjective](#adjective) referring to an inhabitant or native of a specific place. Sometimes the demonym is clearly related to the place name, as in English [_Mexico_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Mexico#English) and corresponding demonym [_Mexican_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Mexican#English), but sometimes it is not, as in the [_Netherlands_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Netherlands#English) vs. [_Dutch_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Dutch#English). Some languages (e.g. most Slavic languages) have different (but typically related) adjective and noun forms of a given demonym, while in other languages (e.g. most Romance languages), they are the same. English is inconsistent in this regard; contrast [_Mexican_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Mexican#English) (either an adjective or noun) with [_Swedish_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Swedish#English) (adjective) vs. [_Swede_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Swede#English) (noun). In some cases in English, such as [_Chinese_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Chinese#English), there is no single-word singular noun form of a demonym that is fully accepted as [standard](#standard) in modern usage, leading to locutions such as _Chinese person_ or _person from China_.

label: denominal
description: Derived from a [noun](#noun).

label: denotation
description: The [objective](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/objective) and [analytical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/analytical) meaning (definition) of a word, as contrasted with its emotional overtones, which constitute its [connotation](#connotation). For example, the words _start_ and _commence_ usually have the same denotation (i.e., "begin"), but they often have ([subjective](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/subjective)) connotational difference (such that a parent might say, "start doing your homework as soon as you finish your snack and bathroom break" but would usually not say "commence doing your homework […]" because it sounds odd in a certain way (out of place in the context, unless emphasizing the word for humor, vocabulary building, or some other special purpose).

label: dependent
description: (In Greek and in the Gaelic languages) A verb form which is not used independently but preceded by a particle to form the negative or a tense form.

label: dependent clause
description: A [clause](#clause) that cannot stand on its own as a complete [sentence](#sentence), as opposed to an [independent clause](#independent_clause). Also known as a [subordinate clause](#subordinate_clause). Logically, a dependent clause modifies a word in another clause in the sentence. Common examples are (1) [relative clauses](#relative_clause) (also known as "adjective clauses" or "adjectival clauses"), which modify nouns (e.g. _The man whom I saw yesterday is leaving today_); (2) [adverbial clauses](#adverbial_clause), which modify verbs in an adverbial fashion (e.g. _When it is time to leave, I will go home_), and [noun clauses](#noun_clause), which take the place of nouns (e.g. _I said that my name is John_ or _I suggested that he leave_).

label: deponent
description: (In Greek, Latin, and some Gaelic and Nordic languages) A verb with an active meaning which conjugates in a passive manner.

label: derived terms
description: A post-[POS](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/POS) heading listing terms in the same language that are morphological derivatives. Confusingly, "derived" is also used in etymology sections to indicate that the term comes from a term in _another_ language, but is not directly [borrowed](#loanword) or [inherited](#inherited).

label: derogatory
description: _See [_pejorative_](#pejorative)._

label: descendants
description: A post-[POS](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/POS) heading listing terms in other languages that have borrowed or inherited the word.

label: descriptive
description: Concerning [linguistic description](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/linguistic_description): how a language is [in fact](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/in_fact) used (as evidenced by [corpora](#corpus)), as contrasted with how some people think that it [ought to](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ought_to) be used, which is sometimes different; compare [_prescriptive_](#prescriptive). (Also: [Wiktionary's policy upholding description](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Neutral_point_of_view#In_the_treatment_of_words).)

label: descriptive compound
description: A [nominal](#nominal) [compound](#compound) in which one part modifies the other, where both parts refer to the intended meaning of the compound as a whole. Also known as a [_karmadharaya_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/karmadharaya) compound. The intended meaning of the compound as a whole is an extension of the sum-of-parts meaning of the compound. Examples in English are "[blackboard](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/blackboard)" (a type of board which is [often] black) and "[houseboat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/houseboat)" (a boat which is also a house). / Contrast [determinative](#determinative) compounds, where the modified component but not the modifier refer to the intended meaning as a whole, as in "[rainbow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rainbow)" and "[footstool](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/footstool)". Descriptive compounds are a subtype of [endocentric](#endocentric) compounds, which are in turn contrasted with [exocentric](#exocentric) and [coordinative](#coordinative) compounds.

label: desiderative
description: A verb form indicating a wish.

label: determinate verb
description: In the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), another term for [_unidirectional verb_](#unidirectional_verb).

label: determinative compound
description: A [nominal](#nominal) [compound](#compound) in which one part modifies the other, where the modified component (but not the modifier) refers to the intended meaning of the compound as a whole. Also known as a [_tatpurusa_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tatpurusa) compound. Examples in English are "[rainbow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rainbow)" (a type of [bow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bow), caused by the rain) and "[footstool](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/footstool)" (a type of [stool](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stool), intended for one's feet). / Contrast [descriptive](#descriptive) compounds, where both the modifier and modified component refer to the intended meaning as a whole, as in "[blackboard](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/blackboard)" or "[houseboat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/houseboat)". Determinative compounds are a subtype of [endocentric](#endocentric) compounds, which in turn are contrasted with [exocentric](#exocentric) and [coordinative](#coordinative) compounds.

label: deverbal
description: A word, often a [substantive](#substantive), derived from a [verb](#verb). / Contrast [_denominal_](#denominal).

label: diachrony
description: A viewpoint of analysis of a language or phrase within a language which considers the [historical changes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/historical_linguistics) over time which have shaped its state at a given later time. The term is typically used to contrast with [_synchrony_](#synchrony).

label: diacritic
description: A diacritic – also diacritical mark, diacritical point, diacritical sign, or an accent – is a [glyph](#glyph) added to a letter, or basic glyph. Examples: [acute](#acute) ( ´ ), double acute ( ˝ ), [breve](#breve) ( ˘ ), inverted breve ( ̑ ), [cedilla](#cedilla) ( ¸ ), [diaeresis](#diaeresis)/[umlaut](#umlaut) ( ¨ ), [macron](#macron) ( ¯ ), [overring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/overring) ( ˚ ), [perispomene](#perispomene) ( ͂ ), etc. The main use of a diacritical mark is to change the sound-values of the letters or cadence of a word to which they are added. Examples are the diaereses in the borrowed French words [_naïve_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/na%C3%AFve#English) and [_Noël_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/No%C3%ABl#English), which show that the vowel with the diaeresis mark is pronounced separately from the preceding vowel; the acute and [grave](#grave) accents, which can indicate that a final vowel is to be pronounced, as in [_saké_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sak%C3%A9#English) and poetic _breathèd_; and the cedilla under the ⟨c⟩ in the borrowed French word [_façade_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fa%C3%A7ade#English), which shows it is pronounced /s/ rather than /k/.

label: dialectal
description: Of or relating to a [dialect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/dialect) (which is, for the purposes of [Wiktionary's labels](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Context_labels), synonymous with [variety](#variety)).

label: disjunctive pronoun
description: A [pronoun](#pronoun) not used in immediate conjunction with the [verb](#verb) of which it is the [subject](#subject) (e.g. Spanish [_mí_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/m%C3%AD#Spanish)).

label: displaced
description: Of an older word: having been replaced by a newer word.

label: dissimilation
description: A phonological process whereby one of a pair of similar sounds within a word or phrase becomes dissimilar: for example, the shift l…l > r…l in the derivation of Middle French [_coronnel_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/coronnel#Middle_French) from Old Italian [_colonnello_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/colonnello#Italian). It has an opposite effect to [assimilation](#assimilation).

label: distal
description: Indicates distance from the speaker. / Contrast [_proximal_](#proximal).

label: ditransitive verb
description: (of a verb) taking two objects, such as [_give_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/give#English) in “Give me the ball” (where [_me_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/me#English) is an [indirect object](#indirect_object) and _[_the_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/the#English) [_ball_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ball#English)_ is a [direct object](#direct_object)). Compare [intransitive](#intransitive_verb), [transitive](#transitive_verb), and [ambitransitive](#ambitransitive_verb) verbs.

label: doublet
description: One of two (or more) words in a language that have the same [etymological](#etymology) root (as in [etymon](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/etymon), not root morphemes like Proto-Indo-European roots) but in the modern language have different [phonological](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phonological) forms. Doublets can come about e.g., as [loanwords](#loanword) from two different but related languages, as loanwords acquired from the same language at two different stages, as one loanword from a related language plus its native [cognate](#cognate), or as derivatives formed at two different stages in the history of a language. For example [_lever_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lever#Noun) and [_levator_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/levator#Noun) are doublets (more at [Category:English doublets](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:English_doublets)). / Compare [piecewise doublet](#piecewise_doublet).

label: dummy pronoun
description: A [pronoun](#pronoun) that has no referent. For instance, [_it_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/it#English) in _it is good to know that you are okay_ is a dummy [subject](#subject). It is used in order to provide the verb [_is_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/is#English) with a syntactic subject, because English does not allow a [null subject](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/null-subject_language).

label: dvandva
description: Another term for a [_coordinative_](#coordinative) compound. / Contrast [bahuvrihi](#bahuvrihi), [tatpurusa](#tatpurusa) and [karmadharaya](#karmadharaya).

label: ed.
description: [Editor](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/editor) (or sometimes "edition"). This abbreviation is often used in attributing quotations; the editor of a compilation is generally the individual in charge of selecting what works to include.

label: eggcorn
description: A word or phrase that sounds like and is mistakenly used in a seemingly logical or plausible way for another word or phrase either on its own or as part of a set expression.

label: elative
description: In [Semitic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Semitic) languages, a stage of gradation that can be used both for a [superlative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/superlative) and [comparative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/comparative). (See also [_degrees of comparison_](#degrees_of_comparison).)

label: elative case
description: A [case](#case) which expresses "moving out of".

label: elision
description: The removal of a [phoneme](#phoneme) or sequence of phonemes from a word, particularly at the beginning or end.

label: elongated
description: With [letters](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/letter) added for [emphasis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/emphasis), like "stoooop!" Usually this is [nonstandard](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nonstandard) writing, but in some uses, such as in interjections, this is normal: "awwwww!", "shhhh!"

label: emphatic
description: Taking particular stress. English's [reflexive](#reflexive) pronouns double as emphatic ones, as in "I myself have not seen it" (where "myself" emphasizes the role of the speaker); some other languages (such as Greek) have emphatic pronouns that they distinguish from [_weak_](#weak_pronoun) or [_clitic_](#clitic) pronouns.

label: enclisis
description: The phonetic joining of a word with the preceding word. In modern (and ancient) Greek this may result in an extra stress on the first word, thus, for example: _το όνομα μου είναι_ (to ónoma mou eínai) _becomes_ _το όνομά μου είναι_ (to ónomá mou eínai)

label: endonym
description: A name used by a group or category of people to refer to themselves or their language (contrast [exonym](#exonym)). Also called [autonym](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/autonym) or [selfname](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/selfname).

label: endocentric compound
description: A [nominal](#nominal) [compound](#compound) in which one part modifies the other, where the modified compound refers to the intended meaning of the compound as a whole. Examples in English are "[blackboard](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/blackboard)" (a type of [board](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/board)), "[houseboat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/houseboat)" (a type of [boat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/boat)), "[rainbow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rainbow)" (a type of [bow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bow)) and "[footstool](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/footstool)" (a type of stool). Endocentric compounds are categorized into two subtypes, [descriptive](#descriptive) compounds (where the modifier also refers to the intended meaning of the compound as a whole, as in [blackboard](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/blackboard) and [houseboat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/houseboat)) and [determinative](#determinative) compounds (where the modifier does not refer to the intended meaning of the compound as a whole, as in [rainbow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rainbow) and [footstool](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/footstool)). For example, a [houseboat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/houseboat) is a type of [house](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/house) as well as a type of [boat](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/boat), and a [blackboard](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/blackboard) is (usually) [black](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/black). However, a [rainbow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rainbow) is not a type of [rain](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rain) (rather it is a [bow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bow) that is caused _by_ the rain), and similarly a [footstool](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/footstool) is not a type of [foot](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/foot) (it is a stool intended _for_ the feet). Endocentric compounds are contrasted with [exocentric](#exocentric) and [coordinative](#coordinative) compounds.

label: enPR
description: Wiktionary's [English Phonemic Representation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:English_Phonemic_Representation) system. Details in the [English pronunciation key](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:English_pronunciation).

label: entry
description: Each language section on a Wiktionary page. For example, the page titled "[invention](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/invention)" contains two entries: one for English and one for French.

label: epenthesis
description: The insertion of a [phoneme](#phoneme), letter, or [syllable](#syllable) into a word, usually to satisfy the phonological constraints of a language or poetic context. In careful use epenthesis only refers to insertions in the middle of a word: cf. [prothesis](#prothesis), [paragoge](#paragoge).

label: epicene
description: Having a single form for both male and female referents.

label: eponym
description: A word formed from a real or fictive person’s name. Compare [toponym](#toponym), a word derived from a place name.

label: eponymous
description: Using its own name as a title for a work of art.

label: equative
description: A construction showing an equal quality; for example, the equative of [_happy_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/happy#English) is _as happy as_. In some languages, such as Welsh and Old Irish, the equative is a distinct form of the adjective.

label: ergative case
description: A [case](#case) used in some languages, which marks the [subject](#subject) of a [transitive verb](#transitive_verb), but not the subject of an [intransitive verb](#intransitive_verb).

label: ergative verb
description: A verb that can be transitive or intransitive, where the intransitive [subject](#subject) is the [patient](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/patient#Noun), the same role as the transitive object. Essentially, an ergative is an intransitive verb that is its own [causative](#causative) when used transitively. For example, [_break_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/break#English) is an ergative verb. The same thing happens to the window in "The window broke" (subject) as in "I broke the window" ([direct object](#direct_object)), but in the second example there is also an [agent](#agent) which causes the window to break.

label: etymology
description: An account of the origin and historical development of a word.

label: etymon
description: The source word of a given word.

label: excessive spelling
description: In languages with [matres lectionis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mater_lectionis) ([consonant](#consonant) letters representing [vowels](#vowel)), a [plene spelling](#plene_spelling) form that includes more of those additional letters that the standard spelling prescribes. The extreme opposite of [defective spelling](#defective_spelling).

label: excrescent
description: A sound in a word without [etymological](#etymology) reason, added for articulatory purposes.

label: exocentric compound
description: A [nominal](#nominal) [compound](#compound) in which one part modifies the other and neither part alone conveys the intended meaning. An example in English is "[houndstooth](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/houndstooth)" (i.e. "resembling a hound's tooth"; neither component refers to fabric). Also known as a _[_bahuvrihi_](#bahuvrihi) [_compound_](#compound)_. / Contrast [endocentric](#endocentric) (with its subtypes [determinative](#determinative) and [descriptive](#descriptive)) and [coordinative](#coordinative).

label: exonym
description: A name for a place, people or language used by foreigners instead of the native-language version (the [endonym](#endonym)).

label: expletive
description: A [vulgar](#vulgar) term, an [intensifier](#intensifier), or a word without meaning added to fill a syntactic position.

label: expletive infixation
description: [Tmesis](#tmesis) accompanied by insertion of an expletive or invective between the divided parts, e.g., [abso-bloody-lutely](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/abso-bloody-lutely).

label: expressive term
description: A term with additional expressive content compared with the basic meaning of the term. This term is common in Slavic lexicography and is found in most Czech, Slovak and Polish dictionaries, but there is no exact equivalent in English lexicography. The closest equivalents might be a combination of _colloquial_ and either _endearing_ or _pejorative_, as the case may be.

label: eye dialect
description: The deliberate use of misspellings to indicate that a character speaks in a colloquial, non-standard, or uneducated way, even though the misspellings indicate a standard pronunciation; the idea is that the spelling represents how the character would spell the words if they were asked to write them down.

label: ezafe or ezâfe
description: In Persian: [_اِضافِه_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%A7%D8%B6%D8%A7%D9%81%D9%87#Persian) (ezâfe). The [possessive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/possessive) or [genitive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/genitive) construction in Persian. See also [ʾiḍāfa](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CA%BEi%E1%B8%8D%C4%81fa).

label: f
description: _See [_feminine_](#feminine)._

label: fpl
description: [Feminine](#feminine) [plural](#plural); of feminine gender and plural number.

label: factitive verb
description: A transitive verb that is derived from an adjective or noun, and expresses the act of making someone/something have the properties (or have more of the properties) of the base adjective or noun. Examples in English include: [_shorten_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shorten#English) (make [_shorter_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shorter#English)), [_strengthen_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/strengthen#English) (make [_stronger_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stronger#English)) and [_enslave_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/enslave#English) (make a [_slave_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/slave#English) of). / Compare [**causative verbs**](#causative), which are similar but are derived from other verbs. (Not to be confused with [factive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/factive) verbs.)

label: false cognate
description: A word in a language that bears a [phonetic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phonetic) and [semantic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/semantic) resemblance to a word in another or the same language but is not [etymologically](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/etymology) related to it and thus not a true [cognate](#cognate). Examples include English [_day_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/day#English) and Portuguese [_dia_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dia#Portuguese); English [_dog_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dog#English) and Mbabaram [_dog_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dog#Mbabaram); German [_Feuer_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Feuer#German) and French [_feu_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feu#French) (both meaning “fire”); Malay [_dua_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dua#Malay) and Sanskrit [_द्व_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E0%A4%A6%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B5#Sanskrit) (dva) (both meaning “two”). / Compare [**false friend**](#false_friend).

label: false friend
description: A word in a language that bears a phonetic resemblance to a word in another language, often because of a common etymology, but has a different meaning. Examples include English [_parent_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/parent#English) and Portuguese [_parente_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/parente#Portuguese) (“relative”); English [_embarrassed_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/embarrassed#English) and Spanish [_embarazada_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/embarazada#Spanish) (“pregnant”). / Compare [**false cognate**](#false_cognate).

label: familiar
description: Describes a context where those conversing, through speech or written word, are well acquainted with one another and in casual situations often use more [**informal**](#informal) or [**colloquial**](#colloquial) terms to communicate. Many languages have [inflections](#inflection) and [pronouns](#pronoun) dedicated specifically to forms that are familiar, in contrast with their [polite](#polite) counterparts.

label: figurative
description: Not [literal](#literal). Of [figures of speech](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/figure_of_speech), words or expressions used as [metaphors](#metaphorical) or [similes](#simile), e.g. saying that a greedy person is a pig or is like a pig, or as [metonyms](#metonym), e.g. using [_crown_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/crown#English) to refer to the monarchy.

label: first person
description: A [grammatical person](#person) that indicates the speaker him/her/itself, or a group to which the speaker belongs. Examples are the English pronouns [_I_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/I#English) and [_we_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/we#English).

label: fl.
description: [Floruit](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/floruit) (Latin for "he/she flourished"). Used when the exact dates of a person's birth and death are unknown to denote a date or period during which the person was known to have been alive or active.

label: focus
description: An adverb that indicates focus within the sentence.

label: folk etymology
description: Re-interpretation of the form or meaning of an archaic, foreign, or otherwise unfamiliar word as resembling more familiar words or morphemes. Compare [**reanalysis**](#reanalysis).

label: formal
description: Describes word choice and [syntax](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/syntax) which is appropriate mainly in formal contexts, such as in official or legal documents, essays, and sometimes when talking with one's superiors or elders. [**Informal**](#informal) terms, frequently those that originate through casual speech ([**colloquial**](#colloquial)), are often inappropriate in formal contexts. See also [_higher register_](#higher_register).

label: fossil word
description: A word that is broadly [obsolete](#obsolete), but remains in currency because it is contained within an [idiom](#idiom) that is still in use; a word that has been _[_fossilized_](#fossilize)_.

label: fossilisation
description: The process by which a word, [morpheme](#morpheme) or [feature](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feature) of a language ceases to have independent function but is retained as a fixed component of something else within the language, becoming a "[fossil](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fossil)". An example of a fossil element in English is the plural [_-en_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-en#English:_plural_noun) in some words such as [_children_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/children#English), [_brethren_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/brethren#English) and [_oxen_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/oxen#English); this suffix formerly applied to a much broader class of nouns. For instances of fossilization that appear as standalone [words](#words), see _[_fossil word_](#fossil_word)_ above. Compare un-[_productive_](#productive). Related to [diachrony](#diachrony) and [synchrony](#synchrony).

label: frequentative
description: Expressing [repetition](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/repetition) of an action.

label: free state
description: In [Berber languages](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Berber_languages), a grammatical [case](#case) or [state](#state) of the [noun](#noun), representing the [unmarked](#unmarked) or citation form. The free state appears in [metalinguistic](#metalinguistic) contexts, in [topicalized](#topicalization) (emphasized) positions, in [predicative](#predicative) function, and as the [direct object](#direct_object) of a [verb](#verb). Also called [**absolute state**](#absolute_state). / Contrast [_annexed state_](#annexed_state).

label: fricative
description: A [consonant](#consonant) sound produced by air flowing through a constriction in the mouth, and typically producing a sibilant, hissing, buzzing or otherwise "rough" quality. In English, there are fricatives that are [voiceless](#voiceless) /f/, /s/, /ʃ/, /θ/ (as in the final sounds of _buff_, _bus_, _bash_ and _bath_), and there are corresponding [voiced](#voiced) sounds /v/, /z/, /ʒ/, /ð/ (as in the final sounds of _above_, _buzz_, _beige_ and _bathe_). Fricatives are distinguished from [plosives](#plosive), in which the air is blocked completely for a short period of time, and [approximants](#approximant), in which the air is not constricted enough to cause the characteristic rough sound of a fricative.

label: front vowel
description: A [vowel](#vowel) produced in the front of the mouth. In English, the front vowels are /æ/, /ɛ/, /eɪ/, /ɪ/, /i/ (as in the vowels of _bat_, _bet_, _bait_, _bit_, and _beat_ respectively). / Contrasts to a [back vowel](#back_vowel).

label: future perfect
description: A [tense](#tense) that expresses action completed at some time in the future but before another action or time in the future; in English it is formed by use of _will have_ (or _shall have_) and the [past](#past) [participle](#participle).

label: gemination
description: A phenomenon when a [consonant](#consonant) is pronounced for an audibly longer period of time than is done normally.

label: gender
description: A way of classifying [nouns](#noun) in some languages. In such languages, each noun has a specific gender (often determined by its meaning and/or form), and other words (especially [adjectives](#adjective) and [pronouns](#pronouns)) will often change form to agree with the noun's gender. See also [noun class](#noun_class).

label: gender-neutral
description: Of language constructs, not indicating or restricted by gender, and thus applicable to those of any gender and to those of no gender.

label: genericized trademark
description: A successful brand name or trademark that has come to refer to the generic class of objects rather than the specific brand type. The inclusion of such a term in a dictionary reflects a [descriptive](#description) fact about how speakers use the language, but it does not control or inhibit a trademark owner's legal rights to defend the trademark's protected status, which is determined only through legal and judicial means. ([See usage notes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/genericized_trademark#Usage_notes).)

label: genitive case
description: A [case](#case) that expresses possession or relation, equivalent to the English [_of_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/of#English) or [_-'s_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-%27s#English).

label: ghost word
description: A [fictitious](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/fictitious) or [erroneous](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/erroneous) word, originally meaningless (not used in practice), that has been published in a dictionary or similarly authoritative reference work or otherwise listed as genuine, generally as the result of misinterpretation, misreading, or typographical error, but occasionally intentionally as a [fictitious entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/fictitious_entry).

label: glide
description: An [approximant](#approximant) [consonant](#consonant), such as /j/ or /w/, that is the consonantal equivalent of a vowel (respectively, /i/ and /u/ in the cases just given) and often alternates with that vowel in different phonological contexts. Also termed a _semivowel_.

label: glottal stop
description: A [stop](#stop) [consonant](#consonant) (i.e. [plosive](#plosive)), denoted /ʔ/, produced by blocking the flow of air in the throat without producing any [articulation](#articulation) further forward in the mouth. Glottal stops are not [phonemes](#phoneme) in English but occur frequently in interjections such as [uh-oh](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/uh-oh) (pronounced [ˈʔʌˈʔoʊ] or similar) and at the beginning words starting with a vowel, particularly either after a pause or (in [rhotic accents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/rhotic_accent) such as [American English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_English)) after a word ending in a vowel. Glottal stops occur as phonemes in many languages, such as [Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language) and [Hawaiian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaiian_language).

label: government
description: A grammatical requirement that a word or sense imposes on its dependent words. With _case government_, the dependent word must be inflected in a particular [grammatical case](#case). For example, the Latin preposition [_ex_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ex#Latin) (“out of”) governs the ablative (requires that the complement is inflected in the ablative case). Also called _rection_.

label: grammatical number
description: _See [_number_](#number)._

label: grammatical person
description: _See [_person_](#person)._

label: grave accent
description: A [diacritic](#diacritic) mark ( ` ) used in many languages to distinguish the pronunciations of [vowels](#vowel).

label: habitual
description: A verbal [aspect](#aspect) specifying an action as occurring habitually: the subject performs the action usually, ordinarily, or customarily. Also called [**consuetudinal**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/consuetudinal).

label: hapax legomenon
description: In [corpus linguistics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/corpus_linguistics), a word that occurs only once within a given [corpus](#corpus), either in the written record of an entire language, in the works of an author, or in a single text.

label: haplology
description: The [elision](#elision) or [deletion](#deletion) of a part of a word (a sequence of [phonemes](#phoneme), or a series of letters) that is repeated (either exactly or with slight change). An example of haplological pronunciation is the UK English pronunciation of [_library_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/library#English) as if spelled _libry_, where the sequence of [phonemes](#phoneme) /ɹəɹ/ is shortened to /ɹ/. An example of haplology relating to spelling is [_symbology_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/symbology#English), from [_symbol_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/symbol#English) +‎ [_-ology_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ology#English), where the sequence _olol_ is shortened to _ol_. / Contrast with [reduplication](#reduplication), the repetition of a part of a word.

label: hedge
description: In [pragmatics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pragmatics), a term (word, phrase, or clause) used to lessen the force of an utterance: for instance, to avoid giving insult or bragging about one's knowledge.

label: hiatus
description: A syllable break between two vowels, without an intervening consonant. In some languages (e.g. many [Polynesian languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynesian_languages)), hiatuses within a word are very common, but many languages (e.g. many [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages)) discourage or outright prohibit them. Hiatuses across a word boundary are often avoided either by insertion of a consonant, such as a [glottal stop](#glottal_stop) (/ʔ/), a [glide](#glide) (e.g. /j/ or /w/), or less commonly some other consonant (e.g. in [non-rhotic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/non-rhotic) varieties of English the so-called [intrusive R](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/intrusive_R), as in [_law-r-and order_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/law_and_order#English) or [_Maya-r-Angelou_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_Angelou)); or by [elision](#elision) of one of the two vowels, conversion of a vowel into a [glide](#glide), or [assimilation](#assimilation) of the two vowels into a single [long vowel](#long_vowel), as in the well-known [sandhi](#sandhi) phenomena of [Sanskit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskit).

label: higher register
description: Belonging to the higher linguistic [register](#register), meaning that it might be used when the speaker wishes to sound refined or educated, in [formal](#formal) situations, or when writing. Such terms are usually less common or known and are not used in everyday speech. See also [_literary_](#literary) which is a sub-category.

label: historical
description: Describing an _object_ or _concept_ which is no longer extant or current; for example, [_Czechoslovakia_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Czechoslovakia#English), [_stomacher_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stomacher#English), or [_phlogiston_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phlogiston#English). Distinguish: a _historical_ term is still in use but refers to a thing no longer in current use; an [_obsolete_](#obsolete) term is no longer in use, while the thing it once referred to may or may not exist. Whereas an [archaic](#archaic) term names a still-extant thing or non-outdated concept, a historical term names a former thing or outdated concept.

label: holonym
description: A term describing something that is formed by other smaller, somehow combined or related things. For example, [_tree_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tree#English) is a holonym of [_leaf_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leaf#English); [_body_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/body#English) is a holonym of [_arm_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/arm#English); [_Canada_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Canada#English) is a holonym of [_British Columbia_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/British_Columbia#English), etc. The opposite of holonym, which describes things that are _part_ of a whole, is called [_meronym_](#meronym).

label: homograph
description: A word that is spelled the same as another word, usually having a different [etymology](#etymology).

label: homonym
description: A word which is spelled and pronounced the same as another word, but differs in meaning.

label: homophone
description: A word which is pronounced the same as another word but differs in spelling, meaning or origin.

label: hortative
description: A verbal construction (in some languages expressed with a dedicated grammatical mood) whereby a speaker encourages an action on the part of his own group; the hortative is for the first person plural what the [imperative](#imperative) is to the second person.

label: hot word
description: A newly coined term, or newly adopted sense of an existing term, that has become very popular in a short time. It is kept provisionally as it is likely to remain in usage, even though it would otherwise fail the "spanning at least one year" requirement of Wiktionary's [criteria for inclusion](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Criteria_for_inclusion#Spanning_at_least_a_year).

label: humorous
description: A word, term, or phrase that is uttered [in jest](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/in_jest) ([jocularly](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jocular)) or that originated in that way.

label: hypercorrect
