description: Incorrect because of the misapplication of a standard rule; for example, [_octopi_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/octopi#English) used as the plural form of [_octopus_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/octopus#English) is hypercorrect because [_-us_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-us#Latin) → [_-i_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-i#Latin) is the rule for forming plurals of [originally-masculine nouns of the Latin second declension](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Latin_second_declension#Examples), whereas _octopus_ actually derives from Ancient Greek and has the plural form [_octopodes_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/octopodes#English) consistent with its etymology.

label: hyperforeign
description: Incorrectly applying foreign reading rules, such as in pronouncing the "j" in [Taj Mahal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Taj_Mahal) with [ʒ] rather than [dʒ], pronouncing [Beijing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Beijing) with [ʒ] rather than [dʒ], or dropping the [t] in [claret](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/claret).

label: hypernym or hyperonym
description: A term indicating a [category](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/category) another term is part of, informally called “blanket” or “umbrella” term. For example, [_animal_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/animal#English) is a hypernym of [_bird_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bird#English), which is in turn a hypernym of [_eagle_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/eagle#English). The opposite of hypernym, which indicates terms pertaining to a category, is [_hyponym_](#hyponym).

label: hyperthesis
description: A form of [metathesis](#metathesis) in which non-contiguous sounds are switched.

label: hyphenation
description: The splitting of a word across a line boundary, with a hyphen at the end of the first part. For example, the hyphenation of [_hyphenation_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hyphenation#English) is given as "hy‧phen‧ation" meaning that it is split across a line break as _hy-phenation_ or as _hyphen-ation_.

label: hypocorism
description: A term of endearment, often a [diminutive](#diminutive); a pet name; something that is smaller in a tender or affectionate sense.

label: hyponym
description: A more specific term within a category described by another term, indicating a “type-of” relationship. For instance, [_alternative rock_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/alternative_rock#English) is a hyponym of [_rock_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rock#English), which in turn is a hyponym of '[_music_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/music#English). The opposite of hyponym, which describes larger categories, is [hypernym](#hypernym).

label: ʾiḍāfa
description: The [possessive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/possessive) or [genitive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/genitive) construction in Arabic. See also [ezafe](#ezafe) and [izafet](#izafet).

label: ideophone
description: A word that evokes an idea in sound, often a vivid impression of certain sensations or sensory perceptions, e.g. sound, movement, color, shape, or action. They may be more common in East Asian languages. In Chinese lexicography, such sense is usually described as _……[_的_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%9A%84#Chinese)[_樣子_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%A8%A3%E5%AD%90#Chinese)_ / _……[_的_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%9A%84#Chinese)[_样子_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%A0%B7%E5%AD%90#Chinese)_ or ……[_貌_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B2%8C#Chinese), i.e. “the appearance of ...”. The attributive form is [ideophonic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ideophonic#English).

label: idiom
description: A phrase whose meaning is unapparent or unobvious from the individual words that make it up, such as [_beat around the bush_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/beat_around_the_bush#English) (“avoid an uncomfortable topic”), [_come a cropper_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/come_a_cropper#English) (“suffer misfortune”), or [_pay through the nose_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pay_through_the_nose#English) (“pay an unusually large amount”). Idioms are often, but not always [_set phrases_](#set_phrase), and are usually distinct from [_proverbs_](#proverb).

label: idiomatic
description: Pertaining or conforming to the mode of expression characteristic of a language. Idioms, [collocations](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/collocation), and [modal verbs](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/modal_verb) are examples of idiomatic language.

label: imitative
description: [Imitating](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/imitate) or [representing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/represent) the [sound](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sound#Noun) of something. (The main class of examples is the [onomatopoeic](#onomatopoeic) ones.)

label: imparisyllabic
description: A word with one or more inflections with more syllables than the lemma form. For example: the Greek [_μπακάλης_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BC%CF%80%CE%B1%CE%BA%CE%AC%CE%BB%CE%B7%CF%82#Greek) (bakális, “grocer”) and [_μπακάληδες_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BC%CF%80%CE%B1%CE%BA%CE%AC%CE%BB%CE%B7%CE%B4%CE%B5%CF%82#Greek) (bakálides, “grocers”) and the Latin [_mens_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mens#Latin) (“mind”) and [_mentis_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mentis#Latin) (“minds”) (compare [parisyllabic](#parisyllabic)).

label: imperative mood
description: The [mood](#mood) of a [verb](#verb) expressing an order or command. An English example is the command _go!_ Commands can also be, and often are, [polite](#polite), such as _please go downstairs_. In many languages imperative [inflections](#inflection) are the same as or similar to [subjunctive](#subjunctive) ones, reflecting the shared trait of non-[indicative](#indicative) nature: yet-[unrealized](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/unrealized) ideas.

label: imperfect
description: The [imperfective past](#imperfective_past) tense of a verb, indicating that the action described happened repeatedly, habitually or continuously.

label: imperfective
description: An [aspect](#aspect) of the [verb](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verb) which denotes an action or condition that does not have a fixed temporal boundary, but is [habitual](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/habitual), [unfinished](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/unfinished), [continuous](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/continuous), [repetitive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/repetitive) or [in progress](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/in_progress). Common in [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) such as Russian. / Contrast [_perfective_](#perfective).

label: imperfective past
description: A verb form of [imperfective](#imperfective) [aspect](#aspect) and [past](#past) [tense](#tense), which is used to describe an action or event which was happening habitually, continuously or repeatedly in the past, as in “Tom was painting the fence” or “Tom used to paint the fence.”

label: impersonal
description: A lack of [grammatical person](#person) altogether, or an indefinite/undefined person. An example is the English pronoun [_one_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/one#English). See also [impersonal verbs](#impersonal_verb).

label: impersonal verb
description: A verb that cannot take a [subject](#subject), or takes a third-person neuter subject pronoun (e.g. [_it_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/it#English)) without an [antecedent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/antecedent). The term [_weather verb_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/weather_verb#English) is also sometimes used in some texts, since such verbs of weather (e.g. [_rain_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rain#English)) are impersonal in many languages. Many verbs that are personal and [active](#active) in English are expressed in other languages using impersonal constructions. An example is the English sentence "I must do it", expressed in French using the impersonal verb [_falloir_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/falloir#French) (“to be [necessary](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/necessary)”), as in _[_il_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/il#French) [_faut_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/falloir#French) [_que_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/que#French) [_je_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/je#French) [_le_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/il#French) [_fasse_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/faire#French)_ (literally “It is necessary that I do it”).

label: inanimate
description: Having a [referent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/referent) that does not include a human or animal. Many languages (such as the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages)) classify nouns based on animacy, using different [inflections](#inflection) or words with animate and inanimate nouns. For verbs, this indicates that they are usually applied only to inanimate objects or concepts, and rarely used in the first or second persons.

label: inchoative
description: An [aspect](#aspect) of the [verb](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verb) which denotes that a state is about to be entered or is in the process of being entered. Such verbs are often translated in English as _become_ or _turn_ followed by an adjective. Some languages have a specific suffix for forming inchoative verbs, such as [_-scō_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-sco#Latin) in Latin; compare [_rubeō_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rubeo#Latin) (“to be red”) vs. [_rubēscō_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rubesco#Latin) (“to turn red, to redden, to blush”).

label: incomparable
description: (of adjectives and adverbs) unable to be compared, or lacking a [comparative](#comparative) and [superlative](#superlative) function. _See_ [**comparable**](#comparable). Examples of adjectives that are not comparable: _annual_, _first_, _extra_, _satin_, _six-figure_.

label: indeclinable
description: In languages with [inflection](#inflection), lacking distinct inflected forms when they would be expected to exist. Indeclinable words have the same form in all cases. For example, the English noun [_sheep_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sheep#English) is invariable because its plural is also [_sheep_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sheep#English). [Acronyms](#acronym) and [loanwords](#loanword) are often indeclinable in many languages. Poorly-attested words from ancient languages are sometimes denoted "indeclinable" when they can't be assigned to a declension class with certainty.

label: indefinite
description: Refers to forms of words that present something as not yet identified or not immediately identifiable; in English, this is the basic meaning of the [article](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/article) [_a_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/a#English); in some languages, this is a nominal or adjectival [inflection](#inflection). In the Germanic languages, adjectives inflected as indefinite are referred to as "strong". In Hungarian and also in Mansi, the indefinite conjugation indicates [no object](#intransitive_verb) or [indefinite objects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_verbs#Definite_and_indefinite_conjugations), including _me, us,_ and the informal _you._

label: independent clause
description: A [clause](#clause) that can stand on its own as a complete [sentence](#sentence), as opposed to a [dependent clause](#dependent_clause).

label: indeterminate verb
description: In the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), another term for [_multidirectional verb_](#multidirectional_verb).

label: indicative mood
description: The [mood](#mood) of a [verb](#verb) used in ordinary factual or objective statements.

label: infix
description: A [morpheme](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/morpheme) or [affix](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/affix) inserted inside a word.

label: inflection
description: The change in form of a word to represent various grammatical categories, such as [tense](#tense) (e.g. past tense, present tense, future tense) or [number](#number) (e.g. singular, plural). For example, the verb [_run_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/run#English) may be inflected to produce [_runs_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/runs#English), [_ran_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ran#English), and [_running_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/running#English). In highly inflected languages, such as Latin, there will be many more forms. Two major types of inflection are [conjugation](#conjugation) (inflection of [verbs](#verb)) and [declension](#declension) (inflection of [nouns](#noun), [adjectives](#adjective), and [pronouns](#pronoun)).

label: informal
description: Denotes spoken or written words that are used primarily in a [familiar](#familiar) or casual context. Do not confuse with [_slang_](#slang) or [_nonstandard_](#nonstandard). See also [_colloquial_](#colloquial).

label: inherited
description: Denotes words which etymologically are not [borrowings](#loanword) but derive through regular or sporadic [sound change](#sound_change), without additional affixation, from a corresponding term in the language that is its direct historical ancestor. For example, English [_one_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/one#English) is _inherited_ from Proto-Germanic [_*ainaz_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Germanic/ainaz).

label: initialism
description: An [abbreviation](#abbreviation) that is formed from the initial letters of a sequence of words. Initialisms that are pronounced as words, such as [_UNICEF_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/UNICEF#English), are usually called [_acronyms_](#acronym), so the term _initialism_ is generally only used for those that are pronounced letter by letter, such as [_U.S._](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/U.S.#English)

label: initial vowel
description: _See [_augment_](#augment)._

label: inline reference
description: A reference whose point of application is indicated in the text.

label: instrumental case
description: A [case](#case) used to express means or agency—and is generally indicated in English by "by" or "with" with the objective.

label: intensifier
description: A [word](#word) or [particle](#particle) that heightens the intensity of meaning of a term.

label: intensive
description: A word form expressing great size, power or emotion. Opposite of [diminutive](#diminutive).

label: interfix
description: An [empty morph](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/empty_morph) (or meaningless morph) inserted between two [morphemes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/morpheme) in the process of word formation, such as [_-i-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-i-#English) and [_-o-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-o-#English) in English.

label: internationalism
description: A loanword that occurs in several languages with the same or similar meaning and etymology, often due to the occurrence of several simultaneous borrowings and/or a chain of successive borrowings happening in quick succession. This commonly results in the exact etymological lineage of a term being difficult or impossible to trace for a given language. For example _bus, doctor, hotel, internet, taxi,_ or _television._ [International scientific vocabulary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_scientific_vocabulary) is a large subclass of internationalisms.

label: interrogative
description: A word used to ask questions.

label: intransitive
description: Of a [verb](#verb): not taking a [direct object](#direct_object); not [transitive](#transitive). For example, the verb [_listen_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/listen#English) does not usually take a direct object; it is grammatically incorrect to say "I listened the concert" (instead of the correct "I listened to the concert" with the [indirect object](#indirect_object) "to the concert"). / Of an adposition (such as a [preposition](#preposition)), or of an [adverb](#adverb): not having a [nominal](#nominal) complement. For example, using the following prepositions or adverbs without a complement (here in parentheses): [_down_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/down#English) (the stairs), [_under_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/under#English) (the bridge), [_inside_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/inside#English) (the building), [_aboard_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/aboard#English) (the ship), [_underneath_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/underneath#English) (the table), [_here_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/here#English), [_there_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/there#English), [_abroad_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/abroad#English), [_downtown_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/downtown#English), [_afterwards_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/afterwards#English), …

label: invariable
description: _See [_indeclinable_](#indeclinable)._

label: invariant
description: _See [_indeclinable_](#indeclinable)._

label: inversion
description: A grammatical construction where the normal word order is reversed. An example in English is: "Will Fred stay?"

label: iotation
description: A specific occurrence of [palatalization](#palatalization) that occurred in the [Proto-Slavic language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-Slavic_language), in which a [consonant](#consonant) combined with the palatal approximant /j/ to form a palatalized [consonant](#consonant). Also, any similar process occurring in a later [Slavic language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) or elsewhere. For example, under certain circumstances in [Russian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_language), underlying _s; z; t; d; k; g_ are iotated to _š; ž; č or šč; ž; č; ž_ respectively (pronounced /ʂ/; /ʐ/; /t͡ɕ/ or /ɕː/; /ʐ/; /t͡ɕ/; /ʐ/ respectively). (See [_Appendix:Russian verbs § Slavic iotation_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Russian_verbs#Slavic_iotation) for the full iotation rules in [Russian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_language); other [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) behave similarly.)

label: IPA
description: The [International Phonetic Alphabet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet); a standardized system for transcribing the sounds in any spoken language.

label: ʾiʿrāb
description: Also called [desinential inflection](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/desinential_inflection); in Arabic: [_إِعْرَاب_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%A5%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A8#Arabic) (ʔiʕrāb). A number of [inflectional](#inflection) endings, applied to Arabic nouns, adjectives, and verbs, which—with minor exceptions—do not appear in writing, and moreover are not pronounced in [pausa](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pausa), i.e. at the end of a sentence or before a pause. Nevertheless, these endings are a regular and required element of Qur'ānic and Classical Arabic. In Modern Standard Arabic, however, they are rather often avoided due to dialectal influence. In nouns and adjectives, the ʾiʿrāb primarily has the function of marking the cases ([nominative](#nominative), [genitive](#genitive), [accusative](#accusative)), while in verbs it marks the moods ([indicative](#indicative), [subjunctive](#subjunctive), [jussive](#jussive)). All of these are only occasionally distinguishable without application of the ʾiʿrāb.

label: irregular
description: Not following the usual rules of [inflection](#inflection); for example, the plural of English [_man_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/man#English) is [_men_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/men#English), which is irregular; the regularly formed plural would have been *_mans_.

label: iterative
description: Expressive of an action that is repeated with frequency.

label: izafet
description: The [possessive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/possessive) or [genitive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/genitive) construction in [Turkic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkic_languages) such as [Azerbaijani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azerbaijani). The term, and sometimes the grammatical structure, is borrowed from Persian [_اِضافِه_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%A7%D8%B6%D8%A7%D9%81%D9%87#Persian) (ezâfe) (see [ezafe](#ezafe)), which comes in turn from Arabic [_إِضَافَة_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D8%A5%D8%B6%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%A9#Arabic) (ʔiḍāfa) (see [ʾiḍāfa](#ʾiḍāfa)). Native _izafet_ constructions in Turkic languages are right-headed (the first term modifies the second), but some constructions (especially in elevated or older style, such as [Classical Azerbaijani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_Azerbaijani) and [Ottoman Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish)) are left-headed in imitation of Persian grammar. There are three native _izafet_ constructions: (a) type I, where both nouns are zero-marked; (b) type II, where the first noun is zero-marked and the second receives a possessive suffix; and (c) type III, where the first noun is in the genitive case and the second receives a possessive suffix.

label: jussive mood
description: In certain languages (e.g. Hebrew, Arabic and Esperanto), a [mood](#mood) of a [verb](#verb) used to indicate a command, permission or agreement with a request (distinct from the [imperative](#imperative_mood)).

label: karmadharaya
description: Another term for a [_descriptive compound_](#descriptive_compound). / Contrast [bahuvrihi](#bahuvrihi), [tatpurusa](#tatpurusa) and [dvandva](#dvandva).

label: Katharevousa
description: The [classically](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/classical_language) based artificial ([standardized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/standard_language)) Greek language created at the start of Greece's independence from the [Ottoman Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Empire). It was used for all formal and official purposes until 1976.(Note: In Wiktionary, Katharevousa terms are entered under (modern) [Greek](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Greek_language).)

label: kenning
description: A [metaphorical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/metaphorical) compound or phrase describing basic objects in an [allusive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/allusive) fashion, especially in Germanic poetry.

label: Kulturwort
description: A type of [Wanderwort](#wanderwort) which is specific to a particular culture or which is spread by an influential cross-cultural phenomenon. Kulturworts (or _Kulturwörter_) are often names of products distributed by trade and religious or ideological terms.

label: learned borrowing
description: A [loanword](#loanword) that was borrowed directly on purpose, instead of through normal [language contact](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/language_contact), from another language, especially [classical languages](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/classical_language) such as Latin, Ancient Greek or Sanskrit, and which has not undergone significant reshaping due to [sound change](#sound_change) or analogy with inherited terms. Such borrowings are thus often [unadapted](#unadapted_borrowing). Compare with [semi-learned borrowings](#semi-learned_borrowing), which have been significantly reshaped ([adapted](#adapted_borrowing)), and [inherited](#inherited) terms, which have undergone all the normal sound changes of a language. A theme of Latin's influence on modern European languages is that in many cases the same Latin word has been borrowed into any given modern language multiple times in different eras, and the morphologic and semantic facts about each descendant word differ in predictable ways (by eras); a concise summary for the case of English (for example) is offered in some introductory textbooks, such as Burriss and Casson. A typical example of this process is that the Portuguese term [_artículo_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/art%C3%ADculo#Portuguese) (“[articulus](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/articulus)”) is a learned borrowing from Latin [_articulus_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/articulus#Latin) (“joint, limb, division”); the term [_artigo_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/artigo#Portuguese) (“article”) is a semi-learned borrowing from the same term, which was borrowed early enough to undergo later sound changes that [lenited](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lenite) _c_ into _g_ and deleted _l_ between vowels; and the term [_artelho_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/artelho#Portuguese) (“toe”) is inherited from the same Latin term.

label: lemma
description: The headword or citation form of an [inflected](#inflection) word, i.e. the form under which a word is found in a dictionary. For example, in English, nouns are usually listed under their singular form (_apple_, rather than _apples_), and verbs under their infinitive form (_open_, rather than _opens_, _opened_ or _opening_). Which form is used as the lemma varies from language to language. For verbs, for example, French, German, Spanish and many other European languages use the [infinitive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/infinitive), but Latin, Greek and Bulgarian use the [first-person](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/first-person) [singular](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/singular) [present](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/present) [indicative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/indicative), while Macedonian uses the [third-person](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/third-person) [singular](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/singular) [present](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/present) [indicative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/indicative), and Arabic and Hebrew use the [masculine](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/masculine) [third-person](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/third-person) [singular](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/singular) [past](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/past) [indicative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/indicative). See also [Wiktionary:Lemmas](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Lemmas).

label: letter case
description: The distinction between [majuscule](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/majuscule) ([uppercase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/uppercase)) and [minuscule](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/minuscule) ([lowercase](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lowercase)) letters.

label: lexeme
description: The abstract "word" underlying a set of inflections; for example, _gives_ and _given_ belong to the same lexeme, which is usually identified by its lemma form [_give_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/give#English). See also: (1) [Wikipedia's article on lexemes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/lexeme), (2) [Wiktionary:Languages with more than one grammatical gender](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Languages_with_more_than_one_grammatical_gender), (3) [conjugation](#C) and (4) [declension](#D).

label: liaison
description: The phonological fusion of two consecutive words and the manner in which this occurs, for example intrusion, consonant–vowel linking, etc.

label: ligature
description: A character that visually combines multiple letters, such as [_æ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%C3%A6#Translingual), [_œ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%C5%93#Translingual), [_ß_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%C3%9F#Translingual) or [_ĳ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%C4%B3#Translingual).

label: linking verb
description: Another term for [copula](#copula).

label: literal
description: Exactly as stated; read or understood without additional interpretation; not [figurative](#figurative) or [metaphorical](#metaphorical).

label: literary
description: A [higher](#higher_register) [register](#register) found mainly in literature.

label: litotes
description: Stating a positive by negating the negative — a form of understatement. ("I am not unaware of your difficulties.")

label: loanblend
description: A [partial calque](#partial_calque).

label: locative case
description: [Locative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/locative). A [case](#case) used to indicate place, or the place where, or wherein. It corresponds roughly to the English prepositions "in", "on", "at", and "by". Some languages use the same locative case construct to indicate when, so the English phrase "in summer" would use the locative case construct.

label: locative-qualitative case
description: Nouns in the form of the locative-qualitative case are qualifiers in the sentence and signify the locational or temporal mark of the qualified word. The qualifier is not specific but general or universalized. / See also [_Appendix:Uyghur nouns_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Uyghur_nouns).

label: logophoricity
description: Logophorical pronouns (logophors) are personal pronouns in some languages (such as Ainu, Ewe and Japanese) that marks the speaker when being quoted (or the entity whose thoughts or feelings are being reported). See also: [Wikipedia's article on logophoricity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/logophoricity).

label: loosely
description: Indicates an imprecise use of words; short for _loosely speaking_. For most practical purposes, synonymous with [broadly](#broad). / Contrast _strict_ or _narrow_ sense; [_strictly_](#strictly).

label: m
description: _See [_masculine_](#masculine)._

label: mpl
description: [Masculine](#masculine) [plural](#plural).

label: macron
description: A short, straight, horizontal [diacritical](#diacritic) mark ( ¯ ) placed over any of various letters, usually to indicate that the pronunciation of a [vowel](#vowel) is long.

label: marked
description: The quality of a sound (etc.) to [stand out](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stand_out) in some way compared to a more [trivial](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/trivial) or [default](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/default) counterpart (which is **unmarked**), such as by requiring an extra [feature](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feature) to [articulate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/articulate) or by carrying a [morphological](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/morphological) power absent from the unmarked form.

label: mass noun
description: _See [_uncountable_](#uncountable)._

label: measure word
description: _See [_counter_](#counter)._

label: mediopassive
description: The grammatical [voice](#voice) that subsumes the meanings of both the [middle voice](#middle_voice) and [passive voice](#passive_voice). Several languages (e.g. [Sanskrit](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Sanskrit), [Greek](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Greek), [Icelandic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Icelandic) and [Albanian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Albanian)) make a [morphological](#morphology) distinction between active and mediopassive voices, and in such languages, the mediopassive can have either middle, passive or (often) [reflexive](#reflexive) semantics. Often used interchangeably with the [middle voice](#middle_voice).

label: men 's speech
description: In certain languages (for example, [Karajá language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karaj%C3%A1_language)), men and women use or historically used distinct words and inflected forms. / Compare [women's speech](#women's_speech).

label: merger
description: In etymology, a [confluence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/confluence) of two etymologically separate sources into eventually one and the same term, motivated by a coincidental [phono-semantic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phono-semantic) similarity between them. For example, Old English [_nǣmel_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/n%C3%A6mel#Old_English) (“receptive, quick to grasp”) and [_numol_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/numol#Old_English) (“able to take, capable of holding”) apparently merged into English [_nimble_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nimble#English), which absorbed the [semantics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/semantics) of both words. An extreme type of [conflation](#conflation). Contrast [_blend_](#blend). In phonology, a [sound change](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sound_change) that results in two [phonemes](#phoneme) (typically referring to [vowels](#vowel)) becoming one phoneme as a result of increasingly similar pronunciation over time. This need not affect an entire language, but will (at least initially) apply to a particular [variety](#variety) of the language, such as one regional “[accent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/accent)” or [dialect](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dialect). Example: the recent [cot-caught merger](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cot-caught_merger) affecting some English speakers.

label: meronym
description: A term that denotes a part of the whole that is denoted by another term. For example, the word "arm" is a **meronym** of the word "body". The term which describes the _whole_, as being an opposite of meronym, is [_holonym_](#holonym).

label: metaphorical
description: The use of a word or phrase as a [metaphor](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/metaphor) to refer to something that it is not, invoking a direct similarity between the word or phrase used and the thing described. See also [simile](#simile) and [figurative](#figurative).

label: metanalysis
description: _See [_rebracketing_](#rebracketing)._

label: metathesis
description: A [sound change](#sound_change) in which two sounds or groups of sounds exchange position in a word. A form showing metathesis is described as [_metathetic_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/metathetic#English). The sounds may be adjacent, as in [_ax_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ax#English), the metathetic form of the verb [_ask_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ask#English), or farther apart, as in Spanish [_palabra_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/palabra#Spanish) from Latin [_parabola_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/parabola#Latin); there, the sound change is [hyperthesis](#hyperthesis).

label: metonym
description: A figure of speech which substitutes one part for the whole. For example, to count how many cattle in a herd, one counts the heads. To describe the herd, one would say, "There are fifty head of cattle." This does not mean there are only heads, but the head is substituting for the whole animal.

label: middle voice
description: The [voice](#voice) verb form in which the [subject](#subject) of a verb performs some action upon itself, as in the English sentence _The plane landed_ (contrast [active voice](#active_voice) _The pilot landed the plane_ and [passive voice](#passive_voice) _The plane was landed (by the pilot)_). Often used interchangeably with the [mediopassive voice](#mediopassive_voice). In some languages, such as [Sanskrit](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Sanskrit), [Ancient Greek](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek), [Icelandic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Icelandic) and [Albanian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Albanian), the middle voice is distinguished [morphologically](#morphology) from the active voice. [Ancient Greek](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek), in particular, has a three-way morphological distinction between active, middle and passive voices in the [aorist](#aorist) and [future](#future) tenses.

label: minced oath
description: A euphemism based on a profanity that has been altered to reduce or remove the objectionable characteristics of the original expression. Examples in English include [_heck_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/heck#English) instead of [_hell_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hell#English) and [_dang_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dang#English) instead of [_damn_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/damn#English).

label: mixed
description: A type of declension in German that uses endings that are a combination of [strong](#strong_declension) and [weak](#weak_declension) endings. In adjectives, the mixed declension is used when accompanied by an indefinite article, or more generally by an [_ein_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ein#German)-word (a determiner that has a null ending in the nominative masculine and neuter singular, similar to the indefinite article [_ein_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ein#German)). The mixed declension uses strong endings precisely in those inflections where the indefinite article has a null ending, and weak endings otherwise. By analogy, nouns declined according to the mixed declension look like strong nouns in the singular (with genitive in _-s_ and/or _-es_) but weak nouns in the plural (with plural in _-n_ and/or _-en_). Most mixed nouns were once weak nouns that have transitioned to strong nouns in the singular but maintain the original weak plural ending. See [Category:German mixed nouns](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:German_mixed_nouns) for a list of German mixed nouns.

label: monolectic
description: Used of a grammatical form accomplished with one word (compare [polylectic](#polylectic) and [periphrastic](#periphrastic)).

label: monosyllable
description: A word consisting of only one [syllable](#syllable).

label: mood
description: One of the forms of a [verb](#verb), used to indicate the speaker's attitude toward what they are saying (e.g. a statement of fact, of desire, of command, etc.). Examples include [indicative](#indicative_mood), [subjunctive](#subjunctive_mood), [imperative](#imperative_mood), [conditional](#conditional_mood).

label: morphological
description: In [linguistics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/linguistics), the study of words and how they are formed from component parts ([morphemes](#morpheme)). It also refers to the structure of the words themselves. Some languages lean more heavily on morphology to carry grammatical distinctions, while others rely more on [syntax](#syntax). Compare English _I make_, _I will make_, _it is made_ (using syntax to encode [person](#person), [tense](#tense) and [voice](#voice) distinctions) vs. Latin [_faciō_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/facio#Latin), [_facem_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/facem#Latin), [_facitur_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/facitur#Latin) (using morphology).

label: multidirectional verb
description: In the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), a verb of motion whose motion is multidirectional (as opposed to unidirectional) or indirect, or whose action is repeated or in a series ([iterative](#iterative)). Also called an [abstract verb](#abstract_verb) or [indeterminate verb](#indeterminate_verb). The opposite type of verb, which expresses a single, completed action, is termed a [unidirectional verb](#unidirectional_verb) (also [concrete verb](#concrete_verb) or [determinate verb](#determinate_verb)). Motion verbs in the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) come in multidirectional/unidirectional lexical pairs, e.g. Russian [_ходи́ть_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8C#Russian) (xodítʹ, “to [go](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/go)”, multidirectional) vs. [_идти́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B8%D0%B4%D1%82%D0%B8#Russian) (idtí, “to [go](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/go)”, unidirectional), [_бе́гать_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%8C#Russian) (bégatʹ, “to run”, multidirectional) vs. [_бежа́ть_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%8C#Russian) (bežátʹ, “to run”, unidirectional), [_носи́ть_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8C#Russian) (nosítʹ, “to carry”, multidirectional) vs. [_нести́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8#Russian) (nestí, “to carry”, unidirectional). English does not make this distinction. For example, "I went to the post office" could be multidirectional (if I went there and came back) or unidirectional (if I am there now), and different Russian verbs would be used to translate "went" in these two circumstances. In Polish coming back does not cause multidirectional verbs to be used, only doing something many times (_Chodzę do biura._ 'I go to the office (every day).' vs. _Idę do biura_ 'I am going to the office (now).') or moving without target (_Chodzę po pokoju_ 'I am walking around the room.' vs. _Idę przez pokój._ 'I am walking across the room.') does. In many Slavic languages, multidirectional verbs are always [imperfective](#imperfective_aspect) in [aspect](#aspect), even with prefixes that are normally associated with the [perfective aspect](#perfective_aspect) (e.g. Polish _przybiegać_). Czech–Slovak languages work differently, as they differentiate between perfective pairs as well, e.g. Czech imperfective _nést_ and _nosit_, perfective _nanést_ and _nanosit_ (the imperfective form is _nanášet_).

label: mutation
description: The property of a sound in a word, often a [consonant](#consonant) but possibly a [vowel](#vowel) (as in [ablaut](#ablaut) and [umlaut](#umlaut)), altering due to its [morphological](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/morphology) or [syntactic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/syntax), as opposed to [phonological](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phonology), context. Examples of consonant mutations include the word-initial consonant mutations found in many Celtic languages.

label: muteh
description: In French, an initial ⟨h⟩ that is treated like a [vowel](#vowel); that is to say, [liaison](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/liaison) and [elision](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/elision) are permitted at the beginning of words that have a mute h.

label: n
description: _See [_noun_](#noun)._

label: narrowly
description: Indicates a more precise use of words; short for _narrowly speaking_. For most practical purposes, synonymous with [_strictly_](#strictly). / Contrast [_loose_](#loose) (_broad_) senses.

label: nasal infix
description: The [infix](#infix) [_*-né-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/-n%C3%A9-) or _*-n-_ in [Proto-Indo-European](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Proto-Indo-European), one of the affixes marking the [imperfective](#imperfective) aspect. / It appears in several of the [Indo-European](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Indo-European) languages: for instance, Latin [_vincit_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vincit#Latin) (“wins”) vs. [_vīcit_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vicit#Latin) (“has won”); Ancient Greek [_λαμβάνω_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%BC%CE%B2%CE%AC%CE%BD%CF%89#Ancient_Greek) (lambánō, “I take”) vs. Ancient Greek [_ἔλᾰβον_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%94%CE%BB%CE%B1%CE%B2%CE%BF%CE%BD#Ancient_Greek) (élăbon, “I took”).

label: negative polarity item
description: A term or construction that is generally found only in negative sentences, questions, conditionals, and certain other “negative polarity” contexts; for example, [_anyone_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/anyone#English) is a negative polarity item, as one can say "I did not see anyone", "Did you see anyone?" and "If anyone wants this, speak up now", but not *"I saw anyone." Several expressions have similar properties, such as [_budge an inch_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/budge_an_inch#English): "I won't budge an inch" and "Will he even budge an inch?", but not normally *"He budged an inch in the negotiations." See also [_positive polarity item_](#positive_polarity_item).

label: negative verb
description: An [auxiliary verb](#auxiliary_verb) used to form negatives of verbs in some languages. See also [_connegative_](#connegative).

label: neologism
description: In general usage, a neologism refers to any newly coined term or meaning. For more information on the term's use in Wiktionary, see [Wiktionary:Neologisms](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Neologisms).

label: nominal
description: Related to [nouns](#noun). See also [_denominal_](#denominal). / As a noun, it refers to any [part of speech](#part_of_speech) that is noun-like in some way, and normally includes [nouns](#noun) themselves along with [adjectives](#adjective), [pronouns](#pronoun) and [determiners](#determiner). The [inflection](#inflection) of nominals is commonly called [declension](#declension).

label: nominative case
description: A [case](#case) that is usually used as the [subject](#subject) of a [verb](#verb). For example, if English had a fully [productive](#productive) case system, then (the) _man_ in "The man threw the ball" would most likely be in the nominative case.

label: nominalization or substantivization
description: The use of a word which is not a [noun](#noun) (e.g. a [verb](#verb) or [adjective](#adjective)) as a noun.

label: nonce word
description: A word invented for the occasion.

label: nonfinite
description: Of a verb – lacking grammatical [person](#person) and [number](#number) attributes; most nonfinite verbs found in English are [infinitives](#infinitive), [participles](#participle) and [gerunds](#gerund).

label: non-past tense
description: The [tense](#tense) of a [verb](#verb) that does not pertain to the [past](#past); in particular, applicable to both the [present](#present) and the [future](#future). Common in some languages, such as Arabic. In English, the main verb in the sentences _I am running tomorrow_ and _I am running now_ can be said to be in the non-past tense, since the same verb can be used to express both the present and the future.

label: nonstandard
description: Not conforming to the [standard variety](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/standard_variety) or [standard language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/standard_language) as accepted by the majority of its speakers; frequently considered incorrect. / Contrast [_standard_](#standard).

label: nonvirile
description: In Slavic languages, a plural [gender](#gender) used for all groups that do not contain men, as well as plurals of [masculine](#masculine) animate, masculine inanimate, [feminine](#feminine) and [neuter](#neuter) nouns. / Contrast [_virile_](#virile).

label: not comparable
description: _See [_incomparable_](#incomparable)._

label: noun adjunct
description: See [_attributive_](#attributive).

label: noun class
description: In some languages (especially the [Bantu](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Bantu) languages), a way of classifying nouns much like [gender](#gender), but determined by other considerations such as the type and shape of an object, whether it is [animate](#animate) or [inanimate](#inanimate), a person or non-person, and so on.

label: noun clause
description: A type of [dependent clause](#dependent_clause) that takes the place of nouns. Examples are _I said that my name is John_ as well as _I suggested that he leave_ and _That the color of the sky on Mars is pinking-red is surprising to me_. Noun clauses can also be [nonfinite](#nonfinite) (i.e. with the verb in the form of an [infinitive](#infinitive)), as in _I asked him to leave_ (compare the [synonymous](#synonym) _I asked that he leave_, expressed using a [finite](#finite) verb).

label: number
description: A grammatical category that indicates how many items or individuals. Examples are [singular](#singular_number), [plural](#plural_number) and [dual](#dual_number).

label: numeronym
description: A [number](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/number)-based [word](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/word) such as [9/11](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/9/11#English) and [24/7](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/24/7#English).

label: oblique case
description: Any case that is neither [nominative](#nominative_case) nor [vocative](#vocative_case). The term is therefore often plural ("the oblique cases"); but in some languages, such as [Hindustani](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Hindustani) and [Old French](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Old_French), the oblique is a particular case form, used for example (in Old French) for the [direct object](#direct_object) and with prepositions.

label: obsolete
description: No longer in use, and (of a term) no longer likely to be understood. _Obsolete_ is a stronger term than [_archaic_](#archaic), and a much stronger term than [_dated_](#dated). See [Wiktionary:Obsolete and archaic terms](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Obsolete_and_archaic_terms). Distinguish: an _obsolete_ term is no longer in use, while the thing it once referred to may or may not exist; a [_historical_](#historical) term is still in use, but refers to a thing which no longer exists.

label: OED
description: [Oxford English Dictionary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary). / See also **SOED** (Shorter), **OED1** (1st edition – also known as **NED**, the _New English Dictionary_), **OED2** (2nd edition).

label: offensive
description: Describing language that is intended or likely to cause [offense](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/offense); [insulting](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/insulting); [objectionable](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/objectionable); [rude](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rude).

label: optative mood
description: A category of verb form (a [mood](#mood)) that expresses wishes or similar meanings. Such a category occurs in [Ancient Greek](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek) and [Sanskrit](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Sanskrit).

label: orthographic borrowing
description: A [loanword](#loanword) that has been borrowed in its written form and re-pronounced according to the conventions of the target language, particularly in East Asian languages written with Chinese characters. For example, the Chinese name [_毛澤東_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/zh:%E6%AF%9B%E6%BE%A4%E6%9D%B1) / [_毛泽东_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/zh:%E6%AF%9B%E6%B3%BD%E4%B8%9C) (Máo Zédōng) is rendered in Japanese as [_毛沢東_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ja:%E6%AF%9B%E6%B2%A2%E6%9D%B1) (Mō Takutō): the spelling is the same, but the characters have been pronounced as if they were Japanese words, leading to a significantly different pronunciation. Sometimes, the pronunciations in the source and donor language have no etymological relationship. For example, the Japanese noun [葉(は)書(がき)](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%91%89%E6%9B%B8#Japanese) (hagaki, “postcard”) was orthographically borrowed into Korean as [엽서(葉書)](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EC%97%BD%EC%84%9C#Korean) (yeopseo, “postcard”); another example is that the Japanese verb [取(と)り消(け)す](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8F%96%E3%82%8A%E6%B6%88%E3%81%99#Japanese) (torikesu, “cancel”) was orthographically borrowed into Chinese as [取消](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8F%96%E6%B6%88#Chinese) (qǔxiāo, “cancel”), and also into Korean as [취소(取消)](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EC%B7%A8%EC%86%8C#Korean) (chwiso, “cancel”).

label: outdated
description: see [_dated_](#dated)

label: oxytone
description: With the [stress](#stress) upon the final syllable (e.g., Greek [_εθνικός_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%B5%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C%CF%82#Greek) (ethnikós), or English [_incomplete_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/incomplete#English)). Compare with [paroxytone](#paroxytone), [proparoxytone](#proparoxytone), and [barytone](#barytone).

label: p.
description: _post_ or after, often used in quotations. Hence, a quotation from "p. 1924" is a quotation from no earlier than 1924. / _See [_plural_](#plural)._

label: palatalization
description: The state or quality of being [palatalized](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/palatalized), i.e. of pronouncing a sound with the tongue against the [palate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/palate) of the mouth that normally is not so pronounced. Some languages, such as [Russian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Russian) and [Irish](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Irish), have pairs of palatalized and unpalatalized [consonant](#consonant) [phonemes](#phoneme). A [sound change](#sound_change) that involves a change of consonants to become palatalized or move in the direction of the palate; one of the most common of sound changes, and usually triggered by a following /e/, /i/ or /j/. In English, palatalization (known as [yod-coalescence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/yod-coalescence)) converted /t/, /d/, /s/, /z/ to /t͡ʃ/, /d͡ʒ/, /ʃ/, /ʒ/ before a /j/ (which was later lost), resulting in the sounds found in _nature_, _procedure_, _pressure_, _measure_, where the spelling still indicates the sound as it was prior to palatalization. Palatalization still operates [synchronically](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/synchronically) before a /j/, producing, for instance, the pronunciations [_gotcha_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/gotcha#English) and [_didja_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/didja#English) from _[_got_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/got#English) [_you_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/you#English)_ and _[_did_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/did#English) [_you_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/you#English)_.

label: palindrome
description: A word, phrase, number or any other [sequence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sequence) of units which has the property of reading the same [forwards](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/forwards) as it does [backwards](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/backwards), character for character, sometimes disregarding punctuation, [capitalization](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/capitalization) and [diacritics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/diacritic).

label: paradigm
description: A set of all forms which contain a common element, especially the set of all [inflectional](#inflection) forms of a word or a particular grammatical category.

label: paragoge
description: The addition of sounds at the end of a word without changing its morphological structure or meaning. Cf. [prothesis](#prothesis), [epenthesis](#epenthesis).

label: parisyllabic
description: A word whose inflections contain the same number of syllables as the lemma form (compare [imparisyllabic](#imparisyllabic)).

label: paronym
description: A word derived from the same [root](#root) or [stem](#stem) as another word; classes include [cognates](#cognate) and naturalizations of foreign words. / A near-[homophone](#homophone), a word that sounds like another word (some example pairs are cognate).

label: paronymic attraction
description: The phenomenon of similar-sounding native words ([paronyms](#paronym)) affecting the development of loan words.

label: paroxytone
description: With the stress upon the [penultimate](#penultima) (second to last) syllable (e.g. [_εθνολόγος_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%B5%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%BF%CE%BB%CF%8C%CE%B3%CE%BF%CF%82#Greek) (ethnológos)). (Compare with [_oxytone_](#oxytone), [_proparoxytone_](#proparoxytone) and [_barytone_](#barytone).)

label: part of speech
description: The category that a word belongs to, with respect to how it's used as part of phrases and sentences. Examples are [nouns](#noun), [adjectives](#adjective) and [verbs](#verb). The part of speech is inherent in the word itself, and is independent of any specific role that the word may have within any given sentence (e.g. subject, [direct object](#direct_object)). Words may belong to more than one part of speech: English [_this_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/this#English) is both a [determiner](#determiner) and a [pronoun](#pronoun), while [_coat_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/coat#English) is both a noun and a verb.

label: partial calque
description: A term which is only in part a [calque](#calque), such that a part was translated and the other was [borrowed](#loanword) directly. For example, English [_liverwurst_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/liverwurst#English) is a partial calque of German [_Leberwurst_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Leberwurst#German): the first part [_Leber_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Leber#German) (“liver”) was translated, but the second part [_Wurst_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wurst#German) (“sausage”) was borrowed without translation. Another case is Portuguese [_verbo frasal_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verbo_frasal#Portuguese), where [_verbo_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verbo#Portuguese) (“verb”) is a translation, but [_frasal_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/frasal#Portuguese) (“sentential”) is a [semantic loan](#semantic_loan) of English [_phrasal_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phrasal#English) (which translates to Portuguese [_locucional_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/locucional#Portuguese)). A partial calque is also known as a [_loanblend_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/loanblend).

label: partitive
description: Indicating partialness or indeterminateness, such as "some water" or "something nice". In Dutch, it is a word form that is used when referring to undetermined things or amounts (example: _iets interessants_ = "something interesting"). French has special partitive [articles](#article) which qualify indefinite [mass nouns](#mass_noun) (example: _J'ai du café_ can be translated as either "I have **some** coffee" or simply "I have coffee").

label: partitive case
description: A [case](#case) that expresses a partial object or an action that is not performed to completion.

label: passive voice
description: the [voice](#voice) verb form in which the subject is not the person or thing doing the action, and is usually having the action done on them (compare [active voice](#active_voice)), e.g. _the ball was kicked (by the boy)._ (See also [_voice_](#voice))

label: past historic
description: A [tense](#tense) found primarily in writing in some languages, especially certain [Romance languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romance_languages). It has the same meaning as the [preterite](#preterite) but is used particularly in [narrative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/narrative).

label: past perfect
description: Same as [_pluperfect_](#pluperfect).

label: paucal
description: A [grammatical number](#number) found in some languages (e.g. [Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language)) that indicates a small number of items or individuals, often around 3 to 10. Usually contrasts with [singular](#singular_number), [dual](#dual_number) and [plural](#plural_number).

label: pejorative
description: A word form expressing a negative or belittling attitude towards the person or thing referred to. Compare English [_artsy-fartsy_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/artsy-fartsy#English) with the neutral equivalent [_artistic_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/artistic#English). Some languages have specific prefixes or suffixes for expressing a pejorative attitude, e.g. Spanish [_-ucho_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ucho#Spanish)/[_-acho_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-acho#Spanish) or English [_schm-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/schm-#English).

label: pejorative collective
description: A word form expressing both (pejorative and collective). Known for some collective words in Russian with [_-ьё_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-%D1%8C%D1%91#Russian) (-ʹjó) suffix, e.g. [_бабьё_](https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D1%8C%D1%91&action=edit&redlink=1) (babʹjó), [_мужичьё_](https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%B6%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%D1%91&action=edit&redlink=1) (mužičʹjó), [_cтаричьё_](https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=c%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%87%D1%8C%D1%91&action=edit&redlink=1) (ctaričʹjó), [_тряпьё_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%82%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BF%D1%8C%D1%91#Russian) (trjapʹjó), for some with [_-ня́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-%D0%BD%D1%8F#Russian) (-njá) suffix, e.g. [_алкашня́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%BD%D1%8F#Russian) (alkašnjá), [_волосня́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BD%D1%8F#Russian) (volosnjá), for some with [_-та́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-%D1%82%D0%B0#Russian) (-tá) suffix, e.g. [_школота́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%88%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B0#Russian) (školotá).

label: penultima
description: The next-to-last [syllable](#syllable) of a word.

label: perfective
description: The [aspect](#aspect) of a verb that denotes viewing the event the verb describes as a simple whole rather than as having internal structure. For example, "she sat down" as opposed to "she was sitting down". As this may often lead to an interpretation of completeness of what is expressed by the verb, this aspect is generally associated with the past and future tenses. Common in [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) such as Russian. This term is often used interchangeably with [_aorist_](#aorist) aspect. Not to be confused with [_perfect_](#perfect). / Contrast [_imperfective_](#imperfective).

label: periphrastic
description: Using more words to produce a grammatical effect. For example, "more fair" is a _periphrastic_ form of "fairer". The English future tense requires _periphrastic_ usage: "I _will write_ an essay." (Compare [_monolectic_](#monolectic) and [_polylectic_](#polylectic).)

label: person
description: A grammatical category that indicates the relationship between the speaker and what is being spoken of. Examples are [first person](#first_person), [second person](#second_person) and [third person](#third_person).

label: personal
description: Having reference particular to humans and other entities having personality such as a named animal, a deity, a personification, etc. Compare [_animate_](#animate).

label: phoneme
description: An indivisible unit of sound in a given language, an abstraction of the physical speech sounds.

label: phono-semantic compound
description: A Chinese character ([CJKV](#CJKV) character) composed of a component which is related to the meaning of the character and another component which is related to the sound of the character, example: the character [_媽_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%AA%BD#Chinese) / [_妈_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A6%88#Chinese) (mā, literally “mother”) ([OC](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Old_Chinese) *maːʔ) is a phono-semantic compound made up of the semantic [_女_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A5%B3#Chinese) (literally “female”) (on the left-hand side of _媽_ / _妈_) and the phonetic [_馬_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A6%AC#Chinese) / [_马_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%A9%AC#Chinese) (mǎ) (OC *mraːʔ) (on the right-hand side of _媽_ / _妈_).

label: phono-semantic matching
description: A word [borrowed](#borrowing) into one language from another in a way that completely or partially preserves both the original sound and meaning. Phono-semantic matchings are especially common in Mandarin Chinese; examples are [_可口可樂_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8F%AF%E5%8F%A3%E5%8F%AF%E6%A8%82#Chinese) / [_可口可乐_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8F%AF%E5%8F%A3%E5%8F%AF%E4%B9%90#Chinese) (Kěkǒukělè, “Coca-Cola”, literally “tasty [and] entertaining”) and [_萬維網_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%90%AC%E7%B6%AD%E7%B6%B2#Chinese) / [_万维网_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%87%E7%BB%B4%E7%BD%91#Chinese) (Wànwéiwǎng, “world wide web”, literally “myriad dimensional net”).

label: phrase
description: A word or group of words that functions as a single unit in the [syntax](#syntax) of a [sentence](#sentence), usually consisting of a [head](#head), or central word, and elaborating words. Examples are _the good boy_ (a [noun](#noun) phrase), _very strange_ (an [adjective](#adjective) phrase), and _in the house_ (a [prepositional](#preposition) phrase). Normally distinguished from a [clause](#clause), a similar group of words that contains a [verb](#verb). Same as [set phrase](#set_phrase).

label: piecewise doublet
description: One of two (or more) derived words in a language that consist of components that all have the same [etymological](#etymology) roots, but which have entered the language at different points in time; in other words, one of two (or more) words that can be split into individual components and all of those components are [doublets](#doublet) of the equivalent components of the other words.

label: pl
description: _See [_plural_](#plural)._

label: plene spelling
description: From [plene](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plene), meaning [full](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/full): In languages with [matres lectionis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mater_lectionis) ([consonant](#consonant) letters representing [vowels](#vowel)), the standardized form including those letters. The opposite of [defective spelling](#defective_spelling). A form with more letters representing vowels than the standard prescribes is called [excessive spelling](#excessive_spelling).

label: plosive
description: A [consonant](#consonant) sound produced by completely blocking the airflow through the mouth for a short time. In English, the plosives are [voiceless](#voiceless) /p/, /t/, /k/ (as in the initial sounds of _pea_, _tea_, _key_) and the corresponding [voiced](#voiced) sounds /b/, /d/, /ɡ/ (as in the initial sounds of _buy_, _die_, _guy_). Plosives are distinguished from [fricatives](#fricative), in which the air is mostly but not completely blocked, enough to cause a rough, hissing or buzzing sound, and [approximants](#approximant), in which the airflow is only slightly constricted, resulting in a smooth sound.

label: pluperfect
description: A verb form of [perfect](#perfect) [aspect](#aspect) and [past](#past) [tense](#tense), which is used to describe an action or event which is regarded as having been completed in the past, in relation to a time already in the past. E.g. _Tom had painted the fence before I got there_.

label: plurale tantum
description: Same as plural only (see below).

label: plural only
description: A noun (or a sense of a noun) that is inherently plural and is not used (or is not used in the same sense) in the singular, such as [_pants_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pants#English) (in the senses of "legwear") or [_wheels_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wheels#English) (in the sense of "vehicle"), is _plural only_ or a [_plurale tantum_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plurale_tantum). In practice, most pluralia tantum are found in the singular in rare cases. (_See_ [Category:English pluralia tantum](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:English_pluralia_tantum).) Contrast words which are **[**singular**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/singular) [**only**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/only) ([**singularia tantum**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/singulare_tantum))**.

label: poetic
description: Language, commonly associated with poetry, that is typically chosen to have an artistic or cultural impact on the listener. Poetic terms and forms may be considered [nonstandard](#nonstandard) or [archaic](#archaic) in non-poetic usage.

label: polite
description: Language that is [respectful](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/respectful), [complaisant](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/complaisant), and (in some cases) [deferent](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/deferent). Many languages have [inflections](#inflection) and [pronouns](#pronoun) dedicated specifically to forms that are politer than their [familiar](#familiar) counterparts.

label: polylectic
description: Used of a grammatical form accomplished with more than one word (compare [monolectic](#monolectic) and [periphrastic](#periphrastic)).

label: portmanteau
description: A [blend](#blend) that combines meanings.

label: POS
description: _See [_part of speech_](#part_of_speech)._

label: positive
description: The 'normal' form of the [degrees of comparison](#degrees_of_comparison) of an adjective or adverb. Thus [big](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/big) is the _positive_ form of the trio _big_, _bigger_, _biggest_.

label: positive polarity item
description: A term or construction that is generally found only in affirmative sentences, questions, conditionals, and certain other “positive polarity” contexts. See also [_negative polarity item_](#negative_polarity_item).

label: possessional adjective
description: An adjective indicating that a noun is in possession of some other noun (or a quality of that noun), commonly formed in English by adding the suffix [_-ed_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ed#English), [_-ful_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ful#English), [_-y_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-y#English), [_-ous_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ous#English), [_-able_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-able#English), [_-ual_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ual#English), [_-ish_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ish#English), [_-ar_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ar#English), [_-esque_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-esque#English) or [_-like_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-like#English). For example, an animal is [bushy-tailed](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bushy-tailed) if it is in possession of a bushy tail, a person filled with disdain is [disdainful](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/disdainful), and a garden is [leafy](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/leafy) if there are many leaves on the plants there. Commonly [idiomatic](#idiomatic), such as in [pinheaded](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pinheaded) or [red-faced](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/red-faced). Not to be confused with [possessive adjectives](#possessive_adjective), which indicate who possesses a noun, or [relational adjectives](#relational_adjective), which are often formed in the same way. See also [privative adjectives](#privative_adjective), which denote the opposite.

label: possessive adjective
description: In English, the term _possessive adjective_ is an older usage for what is now normally termed a [possessive determiner](#possessive_determiner), such as _my_/_mine_, _your_/_yours_, _his_, etc. In the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), however, a _possessive adjective_ is an adjective derived from a proper name or from a common noun referring to a person, and indicates possession by that person. For example, in Russian, [_Петро́в_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2#Russian) (Petróv) is an adjective meaning “Peter's”, derived from [_Пётр_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D1%91%D1%82%D1%80#Russian) (Pjotr, “Peter”); and in Czech [_mámin_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/m%C3%A1min#Czech) is an adjective meaning “mom's/mum's”, derived from [_máma_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/m%C3%A1ma#Czech) (“mom, mum”). Such adjectives are used to varying degrees in place of the genitive case, and show up especially in fixed collocations such as the equivalents of English [_Adam's apple_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Adam%27s_apple#English) and [_Noah's ark_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Noah%27s_ark#English).

label: possessive determiner
description: A [determiner](#determiner) that indicates ownership. For example, in "her book", the word "her" indicates whose book it is. Not to be confused with [possessional adjectives](#possessional_adjective), which indicate what a noun possesses, and [possessive adjectives](#possessive_adjective) in [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), which are adjectives that are semantically equivalent to the genitive case of proper names or personal nouns.

label: postpositive
description: Placed after the word or phrase modified. Compare [prepositive](#prepositive).

label: preconsonantal
description: Immediately preceding a [consonant](#consonant) or consonant sound.

label: predicative
description: Describes a term that acts as the [predicate](#predicate) or part of the predicate of a [sentence](#sentence) (e.g. a predicative [_adjective_](#adjective), such as [_good_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/good#English) in _The food is good_). Some adjectives are only-predicative like [_afraid_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/afraid#English) or [_glad_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glad#English) in English. In Russian, it often specifically refers to an adjective-like [part of speech](#part_of_speech) that serves as the entire predicate of a sentence in an [impersonal](#impersonal) construction. Such constructions often cannot be translated word-for-word in English. An example is [_ску́чно_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%87%D0%BD%D0%BE#Russian) (skúčno, “it is [boring](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/boring)”) in the sentence _[_мне_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%8F#Russian) [_ску́чно_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%87%D0%BD%D0%BE#Russian)_ (mne skúčno, “I am [bored](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bored)”, literally “It is boring to [me](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/me)”).

label: prepositional case
description: A [case](#case) used in certain languages, especially Russian, after certain [prepositions](#preposition). In Russian, it corresponds to the [locative case](#locative_case) in other [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_language).

label: prepositive
description: Placed before the word or phrase modified. Compare [postpositive](#postpositive).

label: pre-prefix
description: _See [_augment_](#augment)._

label: prescriptive
description: Concerning [linguistic prescription](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/linguistic_prescription): how some users of a language think it [ought to](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ought_to) be used, as contrasted with how it is [in fact](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/in_fact) used, which is sometimes different; compare [_descriptive_](#descriptive). Prescription is not the same thing as [standardness](#standard). Example: Both of the following options are [standard](#standard), although one has a history of being [proscribed](#proscribed) (by some speakers, because of [contextual](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/contextual#Adjective) disapproval of degree of [formality](#formal)): "Between you and I, we've got it all covered." "Between you and me, we've got it all covered."

label: preterite
description: A [tense](#tense) showing an action at a determined moment in the past. In general it is thus the union of the [past tense](#past_tense) with the [perfective](#perfective) aspect, although in some languages it is little more than a synonym for past tense.

label: preterite-present verb
description: In [Germanic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Germanic) languages, a verb that displays (or historically displayed) [ablaut](#ablaut) in the present tense, and thereby had _present_ tense forms resembling the _past_ (or _preterite_) tense of a [strong verb](#strong_verb). Most languages have no more than a handful of such verbs, and they are often used as [auxiliary verbs](#auxiliary_verb). English examples are [_shall_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shall#English), [_can_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/can#English), [_may_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/may#English). / Contrast [strong verb](#strong_verb), [weak verb](#weak_verb).

label: prevocalic
description: Occurring before a following vowel.

label: privative adjective
description: An adjective indicating that a noun refers to an object that is not of the class which that noun ordinarily refers to. For example, in the term "fake weapon", the word "fake" denotes that the object is not a weapon, just as the word "toy" in "toy car" denotes that it is not a car. An adjective indicating that a noun lacks some other noun (or a quality of that noun), usually formed in English by adding the suffix [_-less_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-less#English) or [_-free_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-free#English) to the noun that is absent. For example, someone is [beardless](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/beardless) if they don't have a beard, while a coffee might be [sugar-free](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sugar-free) if it contains no sugar. Commonly [idiomatic](#idiomatic), such as in [brainless](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/brainless) or [heartless](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/heartless). See also [possessional adjectives](#possessional_adjective), which denote the opposite.

label: productive
description: Used to form new words and phrases. For example, when a new verb appears in Modern English, the productive suffix [_-ed_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ed#English) is used to form its past participle; by contrast, the suffix [_-en_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-en#English:_plural_noun) appears in many existing past participles, but is not productive, in that it is not (usually) used to form new ones.

label: progressive
description: The [aspect](#aspect) of a verb, indicating that the action described is, was or will be continuing, uncompleted or repeated. A verb form indicating that an action is [in progress](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/in_progress). In English, formed from a combination of _be_ + the present participle (_-ing_ form) of the verb. So one can have present progressive (e.g. _is painting_), past progressive (e.g. _was painting_), future progressive (e.g. _will be painting_), etc. Similar to, but less general than, the [imperfective](#imperfective) [aspect](#aspect). (See also [_continuous_](#continuous).)

label: pronominal verb
description: A form of [verb](#verb) that has an attached [pronoun](#pronoun); this is a prominent feature of [Romance](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Romance_language) and Slavic languages. The verb–pronoun combination can have [reflexive](#reflexive), [reciprocal](#reciprocal), [passive](#passive), [subjective](#subjective) or [idiomatic](#idiomatic) semantics.

label: pronunciation spelling
description: A respelling that more closely reflects the pronunciation of a word.

label: proparoxytone
description: With the stress upon the [antepenultimate](#antepenultimate) (third to last) syllable (e.g. [_εθνικότητα_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CE%B5%CE%B8%CE%BD%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C%CF%84%CE%B7%CF%84%CE%B1#Greek) (ethnikótita)). (Compare with [_oxytone_](#oxytone), [_paroxytone_](#paroxytone), and [_barytone_](#barytone).)

label: proscribed
description: Some authorities or commentators recommend against or warn against the listed usage. Wiktionary's use of this label does not mean that Wiktionary itself advocates the proscribing, nor that all speakers of the language agree with the proscribing. Wiktionary does not issue editorial opinions but rather simply reports facts about usage, including usage advice that exists and that some people follow because, for example, a citable [reference work](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/reference_work#English) is known (by many speakers) to recommend it. Proscribing (forbidding) is understandable both (1) as the negative _type_ of [prescribing](#prescriptive) when the latter means "dictating [dos and don'ts](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dos_and_don%27ts)" and (2) as the [opposite](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/opposite#Noun) of [prescribing](#prescriptive) when the latter means "preferring".

label: prothesis
description: The prepending of [phonemes](#phoneme) at the beginning of a word without changing its morphological structure, as in [_nother_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nother#English), from [_other_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/other#English) (“a whole nother thing”, via [tmesis](#tmesis)), or Spanish [_esfera_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/esfera#Spanish) from Latin [_sphaera_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sphaera#Latin) (“sphere”).

label: protologism
description: A [neologism](#neologism) or any coined word with very limited use. By definition, protologisms do not meet Wiktionary's [criteria for inclusion](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Criteria_for_inclusion). / See also [Appendix:Protologisms](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Protologisms).

label: proximal
description: Indicates nearness to the speaker. / Contrast [_distal_](#distal).

label: pseudo-acronym
description: A word that has the form of an [acronym](#acronym) or [initialism](#initialism) but no longer stands for anything.

label: pseudo-anglicism
description: A word in a non-English language that is formed from English elements and may appear to be English, but that does not exist as an English word with the same meaning, such as [_Flipper_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Flipper#German) (“pinball machine”), [_サラリーマン_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E3%82%B5%E3%83%A9%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC%E3%83%9E%E3%83%B3#Japanese) (sararīman, “white-collar worker”, literally “salary-man”) and [_afterwork_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/afterwork#Swedish) (“informal gathering after work”).

label: pseudo-loan
