description: A word in one language that appears to be a direct borrowing from another language, but does not exist in that language or has an unrelated meaning. Examples from English include French [_footing_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/footing#French) (“jogging”), German [_Bodybag_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Bodybag#German) (“messenger bag, courier bag”), Japanese [_サラリーマン_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E3%82%B5%E3%83%A9%E3%83%AA%E3%83%BC%E3%83%9E%E3%83%B3#Japanese) (sararīman, “white-collar worker, '[salaryman](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/salaryman)'”) and Swedish [_afterwork_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/afterwork#Swedish) (“informal gathering after work”). Depending on the source language, more specific terms may be in use, e.g. [_pseudo-anglicism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pseudo-anglicism) for pseudo-loans from English; [_wasei-eigo_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wasei-eigo) specifically for Japanese-language pseudo-loans from English; [_wasei-kango_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wasei-kango) for Japanese-language pseudo-loans from Chinese; [_pseudo-Latinism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_Latin_by_language) for pseudo-loans from Latin (cf. [hocus-pocus](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hocus-pocus), [noli illegitimi carborundum](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noli_illegitimi_carborundum)); [_pseudo-Hispanism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_Spanish_by_language) for pseudo-loans from Spanish (cf. [no problemo](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/no_problemo), [que sera sera](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/que_sera_sera)); [_pseudo-Gallicism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_French_by_language) for pseudo-loans from French (cf. [vive la différence](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vive_la_diff%C3%A9rence), [nom de plume](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nom_de_plume), [triple entendre](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/triple_entendre)); [_pseudo-Germanism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_German_by_language) (from German), [_pseudo-Japonism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_Japanese_by_language) (from Japanese), [_pseudo-Arabism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_Arabic_by_language) (from Arabic), [_pseudo-Italianism_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Pseudo-loans_from_Italian_by_language) (from Italian), etc.

label: quantifier
description: A word that specifies the amount of its related noun, such as [all](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/all), [no](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/no), [many](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/many), [several](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/several), [eight](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/eight), [half](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/half), etc.

label: rare
description: A term or sense that is attested but not used commonly either in spoken or written language, even less so than [uncommon](#uncommon) terms. A rare term or sense is typically difficult to find even when deliberately searching for it, and may be attested only a handful of times in accessible [corpora](#corpus).

label: reanalysis
description: Analysis of a [lexeme](#lexeme) with a different structure from its original, often by misunderstanding. For example, [_hamburger_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hamburger#English), which is originally [_Hamburg_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Hamburg#English) + [_-er_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-er#English), was reanalyzed as [_ham_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ham#English) + [_burger_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/burger#English), which produced words like [_cheeseburger_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cheeseburger#English).

label: rebracketing
description: The process by which a word originally derived from one source is broken down or bracketed into a different set of factors. The understanding of [_hamburger_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hamburger#English) as [_ham_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ham#English) + [_burger_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/burger#English) (rather than [_Hamburg_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Hamburg#English) + [_-er_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-er#English)) is an example of rebracketing. Also called [**metanalysis**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/metanalysis).

label: reciprocal
description: Used to indicate that subjects have other subjects as object. Pronouns can be reciprocal (in English [_each other_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/each_other#English)), as well as verbs [reciprocal](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/reciprocal) quality as [lexemes](#lexeme).

label: reconstruction
description: A word that is not recorded in actual texts or other media, but has been recreated from its descendant forms, using the [comparative method](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/comparative_method) of linguistics.

label: reducible
description: In the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), a word (especially a noun or adjective) with an alternation between a vowel and no vowel in different forms of the word, pursuant to [Havlík’s law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Havl%C3%ADk%27s_law). In Russian, for example, the reducible masculine noun [_вене́ц_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86#Russian) (venéc, “[crown](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/crown)”) appears unreduced (with /e/ in the final syllable) in the masculine singular, and reduced (with no /e/) in other forms, e.g. genitive singular [_венца́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%86%D0%B0#Russian) (vencá), nominative plural [_венцы́_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%86%D1%8B#Russian) (vencý).

label: reduplication
description: The repetition of a word or a part of a word (as few as two [phonemes](#phoneme) in a word, or the whole sequence of phonemes in the word) with no or slight change. Compare [haplology](#haplology), the [elision](#elision) of a repeated part of a word.

label: reflex
description: The name given to a descendant word in a [daughter language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/daughter_language), descended from an earlier language. For example, Modern English [_heat_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/heat#English) is the reflex of the Old English [_hǣtu_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/h%C3%A6tu#Old_English). / Rarely, this word is used in reverse, and the 'reflex' is actually the root word rather than the descendant word. However, this usage is usually filled by the term [_etymon_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/etymon#English) instead.

label: reflexive
description: Referring back to the subject, or having an object equal to the subject. Pronouns can be reflexive (e.g. [_myself_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/myself#English), [_oneself_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/oneself#English)). [Romance](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Romance_language) and Slavic languages make extensive use of reflexive verb forms (e.g. Italian [_lavarsi_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lavarsi#Italian), Spanish [_lavarse_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lavarse#Spanish) (“to wash oneself”)). These are part of a larger group of [pronominal verbs](#pronominal_verb).

label: register
description: A variety of a language used for a particular purpose or in a particular social setting. Encompasses variants such as [slang](#slang), [colloquial](#colloquial), [informal](#informal), [formal](#formal), etc.

label: related terms
description: Words in the same language that have strong etymological connections but are **not** derived terms.

label: relational
description: Refers to a type of adjective in some languages, e.g. Latin, Ancient Greek, and the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), that takes the place of a noun when it modifies another noun. Consider an English phrase such as _chicken soup_. In English, this phrase can be constructed by simply placing a noun such as _chicken_ in the position normally occupied by an adjective, i.e. directly before the noun. In languages such as Russian, however, this cannot be done, and instead the word [_ку́рица_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B0#Russian) (kúrica, “chicken”) must be replaced by the relational adjective [_кури́ный_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9#Russian) (kurínyj, “related to chickens”) when forming the Russian equivalent _[_кури́ный_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BA%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9#Russian) [_суп_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%81%D1%83%D0%BF#Russian)_ (kurínyj sup, “chicken soup”). Generally, adjectives of this sort cannot be qualified by _more_, _less_ or _very_. This concept relates to the concept of the [noun adjunct](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noun_adjunct) or, in English [attributive noun](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/attributive_noun).

label: relative
description: Marking a [relative clause](#relative_clause). Often used of pronouns, such as _the tree [_which_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/which#English)..._. In the [Bantu languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bantu_languages), a [part of speech](#part_of_speech) that resembles an [adjective](#adjective) in function, but behaves morphologically and syntactically like a [relative clause](#relative_clause).

label: relative clause
description: A [subordinate clause](#subordinate_clause) that modifies a [noun](#noun). In _The man who I saw yesterday is leaving today_, the clause _who I saw yesterday_ is a relative clause. In English, relative clauses are often introduced by a [relative](#relative) [pronoun](#pronoun) such as _who_, _which_ or _that_, but other languages often have different strategies for marking relative clauses.

label: respelling
description: A different spelling of a word, especially to show its pronunciation.

label: retronym
description: A new word or phrase coined for an old object or concept whose original name has become used for something else or is no longer unique (such as acoustic guitar where guitar used to mean this but can now also refer to an electric guitar).

label: rhetoric
description: The study and practice of good effective expression. Also, a type of discourse focusing on goals of the speech or piece of writing that attempts to sway the mind of the audience.

label: rhetorical question
description: A question to which the speaker does not expect an answer

label: rhotacism
description: A [sound change](#sound_change) that converts one consonant (usually a voiced alveolar consonant /d/, /z/, /l/, /n/) to a [rhotic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rhotic) consonant in a certain environment, most commonly /z/ to /r/. The opposite process: changing /r/ to /z/, or to a different consonant, or [elision](#elision).

label: Romanization
description: [Transliteration](#transliteration) of a string in a non-Latin script into the Latin or Roman one: for instance, [_συγγνώμη_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%CF%83%CF%85%CE%B3%CE%B3%CE%BD%CF%8E%CE%BC%CE%B7#Greek) can be romanized as _singnómi_.

label: rustic
description: Describes a word as part of 'rural' speech. Different to [archaic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/archaic) or [colloquial](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/colloquial).

label: s
description: _See [_singular_](#singular)._

label: Schwebeablaut
description: In [Indo-European](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Indo-European) languages, especially [Proto-Indo-European](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Proto-Indo-European), the [metathesis](#metathesis) of a [root](#root) vowel ([unmarked](#unmarked): _*e_) and an adjacent [resonant](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/resonant) ([sonorant](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sonorant)) _*R_, resulting in two variants of the same root (such as _*CeRC- ~ *CReC-_).

label: screeve
description: In [Georgian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Georgian) grammar, a particular combination of [tense](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/tense), [aspect](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/aspect) and [mood](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mood).

label: script
description: A writing system adapted to a particular language or set of languages.

label: second person
description: A [grammatical person](#person) that indicates the person or group to whom one is speaking. Examples are the English pronouns [_you_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/you#English) and [_thou_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thou#English).

label: second-person-object form
description: A type of conjugation in [Hungarian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Hungarian) (aside from [definite](#definite) and [indefinite](#indefinite)) which indicates a first-person singular subject and a second-person (whether singular or plural, but informally addressed) object, for example [_szeretlek_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/szeretlek#Hungarian) (“I love you”) or [_látlak_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/l%C3%A1tlak#Hungarian) (“I see you”).

label: secondary root
description: In Semitic languages, especially Hebrew: A root that is derived from a word that has a different known root.

label: semantic loan
description: A word or expression created by [borrowing](#loanword) a meaning from another language and assigning it to a word or expression which is already considered to have an idiomatic meaning in the borrowing language. Also called semantic calque. For example, the French word [_souris_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/souris#French) (literally “mouse”) was given the additional meaning _[_computer_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/computer#English) [_mouse_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mouse#English)_ in imitation of English [_mouse_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mouse#English), which already had both meanings. Semantic loans are distinguished from [calques](#calque) in that calques are not considered to have a pre-existing idiomatic meaning at the time that they are coined.

label: semantic shift
description: A usually significant change in the meaning of a word over time, either within the same language or when the word is derived from another language. For example, Latin [_ēgregius_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/egregius#Latin) (literally “standing out from the flock”), meaning “distinguished, outstanding, excellent” is the source of English [_egregious_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/egregious#English), which shifted semantically into meaning “outstandingly bad, shocking”. [semantic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/semantic) [narrowing](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/narrowing) A type of semantic shift in which the meaning changes from general to specific ([narrower](#narrow)). [semantic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/semantic) [broadening](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/broadening) A type of semantic shift in which the meaning changes from specific to general ([broader](#broad)).

label: semantic narrowing
description: A type of semantic shift in which the meaning changes from general to specific ([narrower](#narrow)).

label: semantic broadening
description: A type of semantic shift in which the meaning changes from specific to general ([broader](#broad)).

label: semelfactive
description: A verbal [aspect](#aspect), a subclass of [perfective](#perfective), which denotes a [momentary](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/momentary) or [punctual](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/punctual) event (e.g. to [sneeze](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sneeze), to [blink](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/blink), to [knock](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/knock)). In [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) such as Russian, often used to express actions performed once.

label: semi-learned borrowing
description: A [loanword](#loanword) that was borrowed from a [classical language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/classical_language) such as Latin or Sanskrit (especially when borrowed into a descendant of the same language), which has been partly reshaped by later [sound change](#sound_change) or analogy with inherited terms ([adapted](#adapted_borrowing)). / Contrast with [learned borrowings](#learned_borrowing), which have usually not been similarly reshaped ([unadapted](#unadapted_borrowing)), and [inherited](#inherited) terms, which have undergone all the normal sound changes of a language. For example, the Portuguese term [_artigo_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/artigo#Portuguese) (“article”) is a semi-learned borrowing from Latin [_articulus_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/articulus#Latin) (“joint, limb, division”), which was borrowed early enough to undergo later sound changes that [lenited](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lenite) _c_ into _g_ and deleted _l_ between vowels, but did not undergo earlier sound changes, such as lowering short _i_ to _e_. In comparison, [_artelho_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/artelho#Portuguese) (“toe”) is inherited from the same Latin term, and [_artículo_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/art%C3%ADculo#Portuguese) (“[articulus](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/articulus)”) is a learned borrowing from the same Latin term.

label: semivowel
description: A sound which has some qualities of a [consonant](#consonant) and some qualities of a [vowel](#vowel).

label: sense
description: A single [conventional](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/conventional) use of a term; the intended meaning that a definition is capturing.

label: sentence adverb
description: An adverb that modifies an entire clause or sentence rather than a single word or phrase.

label: set phrase
description: [Set phrase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Set_phrase), a common [expression](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/expression) (a [phrase](#phrase)) whose [wording](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wording) is not subject to [variation](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/variation), or alternately, whose words cannot be replaced by [synonymous](#synonym) words without [compromising](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/compromise) the meaning. Set phrases may include [idioms](#idiom), [proverbs](#proverb), and [colloquialisms](#colloquial). For example, _flight simulator_ is a set phrase because it has a special meaning that _flying simulator_ doesn't.

label: sg.
description: _See [_singular_](#singular)._

label: SGV
description: _See [_singulative_](#singulative)._

label: shortening
description: A shortened form of a word(s), including [abbreviations](#abbreviation), [acronyms](#acronym), [contractions](#contraction), [initialisms](#initialism), [short forms](#short_form).

label: short form
description: A shortened term which is itself a stand-alone term; e.g. [_Acts_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Acts#English), a short form used to refer to [_Acts of the Apostles_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Acts_of_the_Apostles#English).

label: sic
description: A Latin adverb meaning "thus, so". It is traditionally placed inside square brackets and used in quotations to indicate that the preceding is not a copying error, but is in fact a verbatim reflection of the source. (For example, if a source contains a typographical error, someone quoting the source might add [sic] to make clear that the error was in the original source.)

label: siglum
description: A letter or other symbol that stands for a word or name; e.g. [_ꝓ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%EA%9D%93#Latin) is a medieval Latin siglum for the word [_pro_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pro#Latin).

label: simplex
description: A simple word, one without [affixes](#affix).

label: singulare tantum
description: Same as singular only (see below).

label: singular only
description: A noun (in any specific sense) that has no plural form and is only used with singular verbs. Frequently for mass nouns. / Contrast [**pluralia tantum**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plurale_tantum).

label: singulative
description: The marked singular form of an unmarked [mass noun](#mass_noun).

label: Sino-Xenic
description: Refers to pronunciations in [Japanese](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Japanese), [Korean](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Korean) and [Vietnamese](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Vietnamese) languages (grouped with Chinese as [CJKV](#CJKV)) of terms or components derived from medieval [Chinese](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Chinese).

label: s.l.
description: Latin _[_sine_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sine#Latin) [_locō_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/loco#Latin)_ (literally “without a place”), used to indicate that the place of publication is not stated in a work.

label: slang
description: Denotes language that is unique to a particular profession or subject, i.e. [jargon](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jargon). Also refers to the specialized language of a social group, sometimes used to make what is said unintelligible to those who are not members of the group, i.e. [cant](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cant). Such language is usually outside of conventional usage, and is mostly inappropriate in [formal](#formal) contexts.

label: Slavic first palatalization
description: A specific occurrence of [palatalization](#palatalization) that occurred in the [Proto-Slavic language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-Slavic_language), in which the [velar](#velar) consonants *_k_ *_g_ *_x_ when followed by any of the [front vowels](#front_vowel) *_e_ *_ě_ *_ь_ *_i_ became the sounds *_č_ *_ž_ *_š_, respectively. The Slavic first palatalization is still an active process in many modern [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages). For example, before certain suffixes in Russian, the consonants к г х ц become ч ж ш ч respectively. Other [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages) behave similarly.

label: Slavic progressive palatalization
description: A specific occurrence of [palatalization](#palatalization) that occurred in the [Proto-Slavic language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-Slavic_language), in which the [velar](#velar) consonants _*k *g *x_ when preceded by either of the [front vowels](#front_vowel) _*ь *i_ (possibly with an intervening _n_) became the sounds _*c dz s/š_, respectively, with _s_ occurring in East and South Slavic but _š_ occurring in West Slavic.

label: s.n.
description: Latin _[_sine_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sine#Latin) [_nōmine_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nomine#Latin)_ (literally “without a name”), used to indicate that the name of the publisher is not stated in a work.

label: snowclone
description: A type of [cliché](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/clich%C3%A9#English) which uses an old [idiom](#idiom) formulaically in a new context. / See also [_Appendix:English snowclones_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:English_snowclones).

label: solemn
description: Used to evoke a sense of current events being highly important. Examples of situations where solemn language is likely to be used are liturgical events, various ceremonies, and public speeches. Solemn terms are often dated or archaic, and once belonged in the neutral register.

label: sound change
description: A change in the pronunciation of a sound in a given language, usually according to regular rules. An example of such a change in English is the deletion of _h_ in the /hw/ cluster found in words such as _which_ and _whale_, making them [homophonous](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/homophonous) with _witch_ and _wail_, respectively. (This sound change is found in most varieties of English, but not in Scottish English or in some conservative American English and Irish English varieties. / See [Pronunciation of English ⟨wh⟩](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pronunciation_of_English_%E2%9F%A8wh%E2%9F%A9).)

label: sound plural
description: In the [Semitic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semitic_languages) and other [Afroasiatic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages), a [regular](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/regular) [plural](#plural) formed by adding a [suffix](#suffix), without internal changes to the [stem](#stem). Examples in [Arabic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language) are [_مُسْلِمُونَ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85%D9%88%D9%86#Arabic) (muslimūna, “Muslims”), the plural form of [_مُسْلِم_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85#Arabic) (muslim, “Muslim”), formed by adding the suffix [_ـُونَ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%88%D9%86#Arabic) (-ūna), and [_مُسْتَشْفَيَاتٌ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA#Arabic) (mustašfayātun, “hospitals”), the plural form of [_مُسْتَشْفًى_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%89#Arabic) (mustašfan, “hospital”), formed by adding the suffix [_ـَيَاتٌ_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA#Arabic) (-ayātun). / Contrast [broken plurals](#broken_plural), which change the pattern of vowels inside a word.

label: sound symbolism
description: The idea that [phonemes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phoneme) or clusters of phonemes carry intrinsic meaning in a language. For example, the phoneme cluster _gl-_ appears to mean "light" in English in words such as [gleam](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/gleam), [glisten](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glisten), [glare](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glare), [glossy](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glossy) and [glow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/glow). (See also [](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/phonestheme) [**phonestheme**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/phonestheme) on Wikipedia.)

label: spelling pronunciation
description: A pronunciation affected by the written form of the word, diverging from the original inherited form. Some spelling pronunciation are considered mistakes or non-standard, while others have historically become universally accepted and completely replaced the original pronunciations.

label: standard
description: Conforming to the [standard variety](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/standard_variety#Noun) or [standard language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/standard_language#Noun). Contrast [_nonstandard_](#nonstandard). Standardness in linguistics is [descriptive](#descriptive), but part of the phenomenon that description describes is the fact that some [prescriptive](#prescriptive) notions can influence standardness via a [feedback loop](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feedback_loop). Usages can be [informal](#informal) but standard, even when they are not [formal](#formal) and even when they are [proscribed](#proscribed) by some speakers. A [standard variety](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/standard_variety#Noun) is often a [prestige variety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/prestige_(sociolinguistics)). This can cause some confusion about [nonstandardness](#nonstandard) equalling [_inherent_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/inherent#Adjective) "inferiority", "incorrectness", or "wrongness" when all it really equals is [_contextual_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/context#Noun) inappropriateness. Within a single language, a [wordform](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wordform#Noun) or [usage](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/usage#English:_language) can be an [idiomatic](#idiomatic) norm within some [varieties](#variety) even when it is not the norm in the [standard variety](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/standard_variety#Noun). (For example, in English this is true of the [zero copula](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/zero_copula) in a sentence such as _He gone already_.) It can also be the idiomatic norm in [informal](#informal) register within the standard variety even when it is often avoided [formally](#formal) therein. (In English this is true, for example, of most [contraction](#contraction) use.) These facts explain the important difference between [code-switching](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/code-switching#Noun) and speaking "incorrectly" ([as if](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/as_if) with _inherently_ "wrong" forms or usage).

label: stative
description: Of a verb: expressing a [state](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/state) rather than an [action](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/action) or [activity](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/activity). Many Bantu languages have a verbal extension/suffix to derive stative verbs from other verbs, often with [inchoative](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/inchoative) or [potential](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/potential) meaning.

label: stem
description: The part of an [inflected](#inflection) word that the ending is attached to. For example, Latin _mens-_ (“table”, stem) +‎ [_-ae_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ae#Latin) (ending, 1st-declension nominative plural) → [_mensae_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mensae#Latin) (“tables”, full word, nominative plural).

label: stratum
description: A language that influences another by [contact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/language_contact), typically due to close geographic proximity (often both spoken simultaneously in the same land) and some form of cultural contact. A stratum can be further classified as [substrate](#substrate), [superstrate](#superstrate), or adstrate.

label: strictly
description: Indicates a more precise use of words; short for _strictly speaking_ ([sensu stricto](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sensu_stricto)). / Contrast _loose_ or _broad_ (_wide_) sense; [_loosely_](#loosely).

label: strong declension
description: In German, a declension of adjectives, and of masculine and neuter nouns, that is defined in opposition to the [weak declension](#weak_declension) and [mixed declension](#mixed_declension). Strong nouns (typically) form their genitive in _-s_ and/or _-es_ and do not form their plural by adding _-n_ and/or _-en_. In adjectives, the strong declension is a set of endings used when the adjective is not accompanied by a definite or indefinite article, and includes a fuller set of endings than that of the weak or mixed declensions (hence the name). Note that "strong", "weak" and "mixed" refer to inherent declensional properties of nouns, but all adjectives can be declined according to all three declensions, depending on whether an article precedes and what type of article it is. By analogy, the term "strong declension" is sometimes used in other inflected Germanic languages such as [Icelandic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Icelandic) and [Old English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English). In these languages, adjectives are formed similarly to German but there is typically not a single strong noun declension. Rather, a strong noun is any noun that does not follow the weak declension.

label: strong pronoun
description: In Greek, an [emphatic pronoun](#emphatic).

label: strong verb and strong conjugation
description: In [Germanic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Germanic) languages, a verb that displays [ablaut](#ablaut). More specifically, a verb that has a change in [vowel](#vowel) between present and past. An English example is [_drink_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/drink#English), [_drank_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/drank#English), [_drunk_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/drunk#English). Note that some verbs show a vowel change, but not as a result of ablaut (e.g. [_think_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/think#English), [_thought_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thought#English)); these are not considered strong verbs. / Contrast [weak verb](#weak_verb), [preterite-present verb](#preterite-present_verb).

label: subjunctive mood
description: The [mood](#mood) of a [verb](#verb) expressing an action or state which is [hypothetical](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/hypothetical#Adjective) or [anticipated](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/anticipate#Verb) rather than actual, including [wishes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/wish) and [counterfactuals](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/counterfactual#Noun). Some English examples are _if I were rich_ and _it’s important that he be here_. In many languages [imperative](#imperative) (command) [inflections](#inflection) are the same as or similar to subjunctive ones, reflecting the shared trait of non-[indicative](#indicative) nature: yet-[unrealized](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/unrealized) ideas.

label: subordinate clause
description: Same as [dependent clause](#dependent_clause).

label: substantive
description: A noun or adjective (or phrase), that names a real object with _substance_. This is in contrast to an [attributive](#attributive) noun or adjective, which names a real object that carries the _attributes_ of the named noun or adjective. In [Mongolic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Mongolic) languages, it sometimes refers to a single [part of speech](#part_of_speech) that collectively encompasses nouns, adjectives and adverbs, due to their shared morphological behaviour.

label: substantivization
description: _See [_nominalization_](#nominalization)._

label: substratum
description: A language [stratum](#stratum) which has lower cultural or political prestige than the one which it influences. Many historical **substrate** languages have gone extinct without ever having been attested, and so they must be inferred from their influences on surviving or attested languages. One such example is the [Pre-Greek](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Pre-Greek) substratum.

label: superlative
description: An [inflection](#inflection), or different form, of a [**comparable**](#comparable) adjective showing a relative quality, denoting "to the ultimate extent". (See also [_comparative_](#comparative) and [_degrees of comparison_](#degrees_of_comparison).) In English, the superlative form is often formed by appending [_est_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/est#English), or using the word [_most_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/most#English). For example, the superlative of _big_ is "_biggest_"; of _confident_, "_most confident_".

label: superseded
description: Especially of a spelling, formerly standard, and still frequently encountered, but now deprecated in favor of another form as the result of a spelling reform. Examples include Portuguese [_idéia_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/id%C3%A9ia#Portuguese), fully replaced by [_ideia_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ideia#Portuguese) in [2015](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_Language_Orthographic_Agreement_of_1990).

label: superstratum
description: A language [stratum](#stratum) which has higher cultural or political prestige than the one which it influences. One historical example is the **superstrate** effect of [Old Norman](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Old_Norman) French on late [Old English](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Old_English) in the centuries following the 11th-century [Norman conquest of England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England).

label: supine
description: A term for an [infinite](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/infinite) verb form in some languages. In Latin, a type of [verbal noun](#verbal_noun), used for the [ablative](#ablative) and [accusative](#accusative) case of an [infinitive](#infinitive). In Swedish, a form related to the [past participle](#past_participle), used to form [perfect](#perfect) tenses. In Slovene and Lower Sorbian, a form related to the infinitive, used to indicate purpose after a verb of movement.

label: suppletion
description: The situation in which the inflected forms of a word come from two or more unrelated roots: for example, [_go_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/go#English) and [_went_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/went#English); [_be_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/be#English), [_is_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/is#English), and [_was_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/was#English). One or more of these forms, or the entire [paradigm](#paradigm) of the word, may then be called suppletive. Examples from various languages may be found from [Category:Suppletive verbs by language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:Suppletive_verbs_by_language).

label: surface analysis
description: The etymology of a term by an [analysis](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/analysis) based on components occurring in the term's language, regardless of their apparentness or [productivity](#productive), i.e. that term's [synchronic](#synchronic) makeup: for example, [_earth_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/earth#English) +‎ [_-en_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-en#English) for [_earthen_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/earthen#English) (actually inherited via Middle English from Old English) and [_bio-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bio-#English) +‎ [_-logy_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-logy#English) for [_biology_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/biology#English) (actually borrowed from New Latin). Some surface analyses describe actual formations of words actively created by speakers, who might not know their historical origin.Sound changes do not invalidate a surface analysis if they are precedented or regular in the term's language and the relevant components are recognizable in the term, such as [_circle_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/circle#English) +‎ [_-ar_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ar#English) for [_circular_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/circular#English) and [_-able_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-able#English) +‎ [_-ity_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ity#English) for [_-ability_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ability#English) but not [_chuva_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/chuva#Portuguese) +‎ [_-ial_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-ial#Portuguese) for [_pluvial_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pluvial#Portuguese), since the change from /pl/ to /ʃ/ makes [_chuva_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/chuva#Portuguese) unrecognizable.

label: syllable
description: A unit of human speech that is interpreted by the listener as a single sound.

label: synchrony
description: The viewpoint of analysis of a language which considers only its state at one point (or period) in time, not accounting for historical language change or etymology (as opposed to [diachrony](#diachrony)). A purely **synchronic** analysis of a word or phrase (as e.g. from the intuition of a speaker of the language) which may differ from its true etymological derivation is termed a [surface analysis](#surface_analysis).

label: syncretism
description: The situation in which two or more [inflected](#inflection) forms of a word are identical. For example, English [_walked_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/walked#English) is both the simple past and the past participle of [_walk_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/walk#English), and Ancient Greek [_ἄλλο_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%84%CE%BB%CE%BB%CE%BF#Ancient_Greek) (állo) is the neuter nominative, accusative, and vocative singular of [_ἄλλος_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%BC%84%CE%BB%CE%BB%CE%BF%CF%82#Ancient_Greek) (állos).

label: syllabic abbreviation
description: A pronounceable [abbreviation](#abbreviation), similar to an [acronym](#acronym) but formed from syllables (rather than letters) of the underlying phrase. Examples in English are the [_SoHo_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/SoHo#English) neighborhood in New York, formed from _South of Houston_ (Street), and the country grouping [_Benelux_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Benelux#English), formed from _Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg_. Syllabic acronyms are particularly common in certain languages, such as Russian (e.g. [_комсомо́л_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BB#Russian) (komsomól, “[Komsomol](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Komsomol), [Young Communist League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Young_Communist_League)”) from _[_Коммунисти́ческий_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9#Russian) [_сою́з_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%81%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7#Russian) [_молодёжи_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%91%D0%B6%D1%8C#Russian)_ (Kommunistíčeskij sojúz molodjóži)), and Indonesian. Sometimes multiple syllables may be taken from a single word, as in [_универма́г_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B3#Russian) (univermág, “department store”) from _[_универса́льный_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9#Russian) [_магази́н_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%B8%D0%BD#Russian)_ (universálʹnyj magazín, literally “universal store”). Indonesian syllabic acronyms are often formed from syllables other than the initial one of a word, such as [_balon_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/balon#Indonesian) (“prospective candidate”) from _[_bakal_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/bakal) [_calon_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/calon)_, [_distan_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/distan#Indonesian) (“department of agriculture”) from _[_dinas_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dinas) [_pertanian_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/pertanian)_ or [_kapolsek_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/kapolsek#Indonesian) (“chief of police”) from _[_kepala_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/kepala) [_kepolisian_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/kepolisian) [_sektor_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sektor)_. Abbreviations formed partly from letters and partly from syllables, such as [_гула́г_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B3%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B3#Russian) (gulág, “[gulag](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/gulag)”) from _[_Гла́вное_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B3%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9#Russian) [_управле́ние_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B5#Russian) [_исправи́тельно_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9#Russian)-[_трудовы́х_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D1%82%D1%80%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%B9#Russian) [_лагере́й_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%8C#Russian)_ (Glávnoje upravlénije ispravítelʹno-trudovýx lagjeréj, literally “Chief Administration of Corrective-Labor Camps”), are generally counted as regular acronyms rather than syllabic abbreviations.

label: synonym
description: A word or phrase with a meaning that is the same as, or very similar to, another word or phrase. / Contrast [antonym](#antonym).

label: tatpurusa
description: Another term for a [_determinative_](#determinative) compound. / Contrast [bahuvrihi](#bahuvrihi), [karmadharaya](#karmadharaya) and [dvandva](#dvandva).

label: technical
description: (1) Specifically related to a particular [discipline](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/discipline#English:_specific_branch_of_knowledge_or_practice), either (a) exclusively so or (often) (b) with a somewhat [stricter](#strict) sense when used in that way; (2) Of or related to [technology](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/technology#English).

label: telic
description: The [aspect](#aspect) of a verb that denotes an action with a definite endpoint or a goal that is tended towards, or rather an action that is [quantized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantization_(linguistics)) (such that the expression for that action may not describe both the action and a smaller part of that same action); contrast [**atelic**](#atelic). A kind of telicity distinction can be seen in English when specifying a duration in a (simple past) verb phrase: telic verb phrases take [_in_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/in#English) (_I built a house in an hour._ _Did you just lose two keys in one day?_)

label: tense
description: One of the forms of a [verb](#verb), used to distinguish when an action or state of being occurs or exists. The basic tenses in many languages are [present](#present_tense), [past](#past_tense), [future](#future_tense).

label: thematicization
description: [Insertion](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/insertion) of a [thematic vowel](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thematic_vowel) on the [root](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/root) or [stem](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stem) of the word to make it [undergo](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/undergo) one of the [productive](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/productive) [vocalic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vocalic) inflections.

label: third person
description: A [grammatical person](#person) that indicates someone or something that is neither the person or group to which the speaker belongs, nor the person or group that the speaker is speaking to. Examples are the English pronouns [_he_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/he#English), [_she_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/she#English), [_it_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/it#English), [_this_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/this#English), [_that_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/that#English), and so on. All [nouns](#noun) are generally considered third person. In some languages (like German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, and Hungarian), the third-person conjugation is also used to express the formal _you_ (sometimes combined with the plural and/or capitalizing the personal pronoun in writing).

label: tmesis
description: The insertion of one or more words between the components of a [compound](#compound) word. It may produce [prothesis](#prothesis); for example, inserting [_whole_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/whole#English) into [_another_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/another#English) yields [_a whole nother_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/a_whole_nother#English) (tmesis), in which [_nother_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nother#Adjective_2) is [prothetic](#prothesis).

label: topic state
description: In Luganda, the form of a [noun](#noun) in which there is an [initial vowel](#initial_vowel). / Contrast [_base state_](#base_state).

label: topicalized form
description: In some languages, such as Okinawan, a topicalized form of a word is a contraction of that word, used as the phrase [topic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/topic), with the topic marker.

label: tr.
description: Translator or translated, often used in quotations.

label: transferred sense
description: A (usually [looser](#loosely)) meaning of a word or [phrase](#phrase) developed from a [metaphorical](#metaphorical) application of its original signification (for example, _hunger_ has the primary and original sense “want of food”, “craving appetite”, whence developed the transferred sense of “any strong desire or craving”).

label: transgressive
description: A verb form in some Balto-Slavic languages that expresses a coincidentally proceeding or following action.

label: transitive verb
description: A verb which requires one or more [objects](#object) (e.g. _I kick the ball_); contrast [**intransitive verb**](#intransitive_verb).

label: translation hub
description: An English multi-word entry that is unidiomatic ([sum of parts](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Wiktionary:Glossary#S)) and exists purely to host translations and enable navigation from one non-English entry to another non-English entry. An example: [two days after tomorrow](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/two_days_after_tomorrow). See [Category:English translation hubs](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:English_translation_hubs) for more.

label: transnumeral
description: A [grammatical number](#number) that is ambiguous as to whether it refers to the [singular](#singular) or [plural](#plural). Found in [Sino-Tibetan](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Sino-Tibetan) languages such as [Chinese](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Chinese) and [Japanese](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Japanese), as well as some [Austronesian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Austronesian) languages such as [Indonesian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Indonesian) and [Malay](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Malay). When a language also has a plural (or some other) number, they are commonly only used for clarity or emphasis.

label: troponym
description: A verb that indicates more precisely the manner of doing something by replacing a verb of a more generalized meaning, e.g. “to boil” for “to cook”.

label: UK
description: UK English, that is, the English of the [United Kingdom](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/United_Kingdom).

label: umlaut
description: A [sound change](#sound_change) where a [vowel](#vowel) is modified to conform more closely to the vowel in the next [syllable](#syllable) (often specifically [fronted](#front_vowel) or [raised](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/raise) in response to an /i/ or /j/ in the next syllable). Compare [ablaut](#ablaut). Also, an alternative term for [_diaeresis_](#diaeresis), describing a [diacritic](#diacritic) mark ( ̈) placed over a vowel to indicate that it has undergone the umlaut [sound change](#sound_change).

label: unadapted borrowing
description: A [loanword](#loanword) that has not been conformed to the morpho-syntactic, orthographic, phonological, and/or phonotactical rules of the target language. For example, English [_cubiculum_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cubiculum#English) is an unadapted borrowing from Latin [_cubiculum_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cubiculum#Latin), while English [_cubicle_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cubicle#English) is a standard borrowing from the same Latin word. Unadapted borrowings are often learned ones; see [_learned borrowing_](#learned_borrowing). / Contrast [adapted borrowings](#adapted_borrowing).

label: uncommon
description: A term or sense that is attested but not used commonly either in spoken or written language, but more commonly than [rare](#rare) terms. In comparison to a rare term, an uncommon term may be easy to find in a deliberate search, but is very unlikely to be encountered naturally. Uncommon [slang](#slang) or [jargon](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jargon) is unlikely to be used even by members of the relevant subcommunity or specialists in the relevant field.

label: uncomparable
description: _See [_incomparable_](#incomparable)._

label: uncountable
description: A noun that cannot be used freely with numbers or the [indefinite article](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/indefinite_article), and which therefore usually takes no [plural](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plural) form. For example, the English noun [_information_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/information#English) is a mass noun, and at least in its principal senses is uncountable in most varieties of English. For those senses, we cannot say that we have *_one information_, nor that we have *_many information_ (or *_many informations_). Many mass noun senses often have corresponding plural [count](#countable) senses that denote _types_ of the mass sense, _instances_ of the mass sense, or _portions (servings)_ of the mass sense. For example, the main sense of [_butter_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/butter#English) is the uncountable sense, so the plural form _butters_ is seldom used, although it occasionally is used to mean "types of butter" (many [_herb butters_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/herb_butter) contain garlic) or "[packets of] butter". Compare also other implicit references to a container and the portion/serving that it contains (_get me a water, order two sodas, have a few beers_). Many languages do not distinguish between countable and uncountable nouns. [Antonym](#antonym) of [_countable_](#countable) or _count noun_.

label: undeclinable
description: _See [_indeclinable_](#indeclinable)._

label: unidirectional verb
description: In the [Slavic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavic_languages), a verb of motion whose motion is unidirectional and expresses a single, completed action. Opposed to [multidirectional verbs](#multidirectional_verb), whose motion is multidirectional or indirect, or whose action is repeated or in a series ([iterative](#iterative)). Also called a [concrete verb](#concrete_verb) or [determinate verb](#determinate_verb). See [_multidirectional verb_](#multidirectional_verb) for more discussion.

label: univerbation
description: A single word formed from a fixed expression of several words. For example, the single word _albeit_ comes from the Middle English expression _al be it_, in which _al_ means _although_.

label: usage notes
description: Additional information on current and historic [usage](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/usage#English:_language) of the term in written or spoken language.

label: v
description: _See [_verb_](#verb)._

label: varia lectio
description: Any one of the readings of a given word or passage in a text which differ from copy to copy, from edition to edition, from manuscript to manuscript, or from translation to translation.

label: variety
description: A form of a language that may be specific to a region, subpopulation, or other delimitation; in Wiktionary's use of this term, synonymous with [dialect](#dialectal) and [lect](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/lect#Noun).

label: velar
description: A [consonant](#consonant) made with the tongue touching the [soft palate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/soft_palate) (also known as the [velum](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/velum)). In English these include /k/, /ɡ/, /ŋ/, as in the final consonants of _sack_, _sag_, and _sang_, respectively.

label: verb
description: A word that indicates an action, occurrence or state of being. The [inflection](#inflection) of verbs is commonly called [conjugation](#conjugation).

label: verbal noun
description: A [noun](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/noun) formed from a [verb](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/verb).

label: verlan
description: A type of [backslang](#backslang) used in French, in which the order of the [syllables](#syllable) or sounds of words is changed, usually with the last [syllable](#syllable) coming first. Examples are [_barjot_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/barjot#French) from [_jobard_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/jobard#French) (“crazy”) and [_meuf_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/meuf#French) from [_femme_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/femme#French) (“woman”). Sometimes this transformation is applied recursively, e.g. [_rebeu_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rebeu#French), a verlan form of [_beur_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/beur#French), which is itself a clipped verlan form of [_arabe_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/arabe#French).

label: virile
description: In Slavic languages, a plural [gender](#gender) used for groups that include men and for [masculine](#masculine) personal nouns.

label: vocative case
description: A [case](#case) which indicates that someone or something is being directly addressed (spoken to), often by name. For example, in the English phrase _He's dead, Jim_ the name [_Jim_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Jim#English) would be a vocative.

label: voice
description: A verb characteristic (expressed in some languages by inflection) indicating its relationship with the subject. The usual voices are: [active](#active_voice), [passive](#passive_voice) and [middle](#middle_voice).

label: voiced
description: A sound produced with vibration of the [vocal cords](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vocal_cord); a type of [voicing](#voicing).

label: voiceless
description: A sound produced without vibration of the [vocal cords](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vocal_cord); a type of [voicing](#voicing).

label: voicing
description: A characteristic of sounds, indicating whether they are produced with vibration of the [vocal cords](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vocal_cord). In English, all [vowels](#vowel) are voiced, as well as all [approximant](#approximant) consonants, but [plosive](#plosive) and [fricative](#fricative) consonants can be either voiced or voiceless. Examples of voiced sounds in English are /v/, /z/, /b/, /d/, and the corresponding voiceless sounds are /f/, /s/, /p/, /t/.

label: vowel
description: A sound produced by the vocal cords with relatively little restriction of the oral cavity, forming the prominent sound of a [syllable](#syllable).

label: vowel harmony
description: A [phonological](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/phonological) restriction in some languages which constrains the [vowels](#vowel) found either next to each other or within a word, such that vowels must belong to the same class in a particular classification, like front/back vowels or rounded/unrounded vowels.

label: vulgar
description: Language considered distasteful, obscene, profane, or otherwise unsuitable for use in polite or formal speech. This type of language is avoided in children's media and can be used in colloquial language. / Sometimes, a [dialectal](#dialectal) or [vernacular](#vernacular) language, one that is spoken in a region as a [first language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/first_language). But also, instead, a language used commonly or popularly as a [second language](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/second_language) (See [_Vulgate_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Vulgate)). Specifically in the context of Latin, the European languages that developed in the late middle ages and early modern period, on the expense of Latin. / See also: [**offensive**](#offensive), [**pejorative**](#pejorative), [**profanity**](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/profanity).

label: Wanderwort or wanderword
description: A wordform which has spread over a substantial area, or to many regions, outside of that of its language of origin, typically due to cultural exchange resulting from travel and trade. Wanderworts are a type of [loanword](#loanword), but a Wanderwort may or may not be an [areal](#areal) word. See also [_Kulturwort_](#Kulturwort). / Contrast [strata](#stratum).

label: weak declension
description: A declension of adjectives and nouns in several [Germanic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanic_languages), which originally had (and in some languages still have) an _-n-_ in most of their forms. The weak adjective declension is used in conjunction with [definite](#definite) [articles](#article). The weak noun declension is simply one of several possible noun declensions, so named because it uses the same endings as weak adjectives. See the Wikipedia article on the [weak inflection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/weak_inflection) for more information.

label: weak pronoun
description: A pronoun of one syllable which is dependent on another word and cannot be used on its own; sometimes called [_clitic_](#clitic). Compare with [emphatic](#emphatic) or [strong](#strong_verb).

label: weak verb and weak conjugation
description: In [Germanic](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Germanic) languages, a verb that forms the past tense using a suffix containing a [dental](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/dental) consonant (_d_, _t_, _ð_ or similar). Verbs of this type are considered "regular" in most Germanic languages, but there are also irregular weak verbs, such as English [_think_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/think#English), [_thought_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/thought#English) and [_have_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/have#English), [_had_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/had#English). / Contrast [strong verb](#strong_verb), [preterite-present verb](#preterite-present_verb).

label: women 's speech
description: In certain languages (for example, [Karajá language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karaj%C3%A1_language)), men and women use or historically used distinct words and inflected forms. / Compare [men's speech](#men's_speech).

label: yes-no question
description: A subset of closed response questions, where the answers “[yes](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/yes)” and “[no](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/no)” can be treated as different parts of speech. For this edition of Wiktionary, they are [particles](#particle).

label: zero-grade
description: In [Proto-Indo-European](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Proto-Indo-European) [linguistics](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/linguistics), an [ablaut](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ablaut) form of a root characterized by the absence of the basic ablauting [vowel](#vowel) [phonemes](#phoneme) */e/ and */o/. For example, _*bʰr̥-_ is the zero-grade of the Indo-European root [_*bʰer-_](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-European/b%CA%B0er-) (“to carry, to bear”).
